review:
Recently bought this (the HP Stream 11) from the Microsoft Store (for $170 - with 10% student discount and 5% off coupon). I like it so far.

Like:
This is compact, feels solidly built and I really love the color and texture (doesn't catch fingerprints)
Keyboard is good (97% size of a normal full size keyboard; up and down arrows are a lot smaller though)
Reasonably fast so far - turns on as soon as you open the clamshell

Neutral:
Screen isn't great, it is kinda grainy due to the matte finish; viewer angles are very limited - ok if one person is looking straight into the screen, not OK if 2 people are watching Netflix
Audio is just average - gets the job done
Trackpad is finicky - disable side swipes (easy to do)

Dislike:
Storage - 32 GB eMMC that allows the laptop to be compact also greatly restricts the usabiity. Just 1 week into using it, it has just 2 GB free. This is after I installed ms office pro 2013 and a vmware software (just these 2 programs!). I have an SD card but you cant install and run programs on it as far as i know... the storage is becoming a major concern and i am highly inclined to return it to MSFT store because of this. I so wish this came with 64GB SSD. I would have been happy to pay upto $50 more for it.

Tips: Backup onedrive on SD card, change default download location to SD card, get windows backup on USB drive and remove partition. You might be able to survive the 32 gb data that way.

Verdict: I really like this little machine - the form factor is awesome. So I am trying to manage with the little storage. Not sure if I can make it work with this little storage though. SD card and cloud can only help you to an extent - you need harddrive space to run programs!

Just over a year ago, I got my first Chromebook, the Acer C720. Since that time, except for gaming, it has been my most used computer for everyday web consumption: Ebay, Amazon, Facebook, Google+, Wordpress, Netflix, Youtube, etc.  I even figured out how to use Crouton to install Linux (Ubuntu) on it, so that I could install Steam for local gaming and Steam Streaming.  While the Acer doesn't have a great screen, or even a good screen, and it feels kind of, well, cheap overall, for the price it was a fantastic value.

With the release of the HP Stream 11, I think Windows has a device that hits a similar value/performance intersection. I've only owned it one day but based on initial impressions, this is a fantastic value and an easy recommendation for a LOT of use cases.

SPECS

The HP Stream 11 is an 11.6" Windows 8.1 Laptop, powered by an Intel Celeron N2840 processor at 2.16 GHz. It has 2 GB of RAM and a 32 GB SSD, neither of which can be upgraded. It is rated for 8.5 hours of battery life, depending on performance and brightness settings of course.

The screen is a 1366x768 high definition LCD screen, which has a matte coating for anti-glare. This is basically the same screen as the Acer C720. Which is to say, the screen is pretty bad. The matte coating takes a relatively low-resolution affair and makes it that much more dull and muted. That said, it is serviceable enough and has decent brightness considering the price point. Just know going in that your tradeoff for choosing this over a similarly priced $200 Windows Tablet is that the screen on a tablet will likely be IPS and significantly better in terms of clarity and viewing angles. However, this matte coating does help very much with glare in overhead and outdoor lighting situations.

As far as ports, the Stream 11 has 2 USB ports (one 3.0 and one 2.0), a full-size SD slot, and HDMI. It has a single combo headphone/mic port.

It also has two down-firing speakers that put out decent sound for the price point.

SETUP

Setting up this device wasn't too bad. Windows 8 has come a long way over the past 12 months. In December 2013 my wife's HP required several hours of updates, and updating my Surface Pro (1st Gen) from Windows 8.0 to 8.1 was very difficult; there was a point where the update hung, and I had to do quite a bit of research to get past it.

Contrast this to the HP Stream 11:  It took 10 minutes to get from unboxing to a functional Windows desktop.  Once there I removed Norton, installed Avast, installed Chrome, and installed Steam, and then installed 35 Windows updates (33 required and 2 optional). This took 22 minutes, plus another 12 minutes of processing after I rebooted, for a total time of 34 minutes. The system handled them all with no crashes, hangs, or issues.

Drivers for accessories like my USB Logitech Mouse and Dell Printer were plug and play with no issues.

PERFORMANCE

This processor/RAM setup powers a lot of 2014's Chromebooks, and thus it has Octane benchmarks similar to devices like the Asus C200 Chromebook and Toshiba Chromebook 2.  My personal Octane scores were in the 7,500-8,000 range. As a point of comparison, the Acer C720 and HP Chromebook 11, with 2 GB of RAM and an Intel Celeron 2955 processor with Haswell architecture have benchmarks in Octane of around 11,000.  You're looking at about 20% decrease in performance.

In general, most websites load quickly, but more intensive sites like The Verge hang a bit while various images and videos load. Once pages are loaded, everything scrolls smoothly. I read some people complaining about Chrome being an issue on this device but it ran fine for me. I had IE with one tab, Chrome with three tabs, and Steam open and the web pages were running fine. I also tested Google Docs and that ran smoothly.

Boot time to the log-in screen is about 10 seconds, plus another 5-7 seconds of loading after you enter your log-in credentials.  Unlike Chrome OS, when you hit the desktop a Windows device is still processing and loading in the background, so the full boot takes a bit longer - but I'd still say the whole process is under 30 seconds and to hit the log-in in 10 seconds is impressive.

I had no problems installing Avast, Chrome, and Steam on the device. I tested Steam Streaming on my local network from my desktop computer and was able to play Wolfenstein: The New Order at an excellent FPS. I also tried a few games running locally including Pacman DX, Luftrausers, and Towerfall Ascension. These ran without issue. I would think that many indie games should run on this, especially those of the 2D variety, but 3D gaming performance will probably be terrible. You don't have much space to store modern games, anyway.  As a Steam Streaming device though, it works fine. And, it should be able to handle most emulation of systems up through the PS1 / Sega Saturn / N64 generation as well as a lot of good retro games on GOG.

Oddly enough, the wireless speed I got using tests on this device were about 10-15% slower than the same tests on my Moto X or Acer C720 connected to the same network, from the same location. That said, the connection didn't drop at all for the four hours I had the computer running.  (If interested:  I have 50 Mb down and up via FiOS. My first speed test showed this was only getting 28 up and 25 down, but a re-test after rebooting later showed 37 up and 36 down)

I haven't had the device long enough to test the battery but I would expect 8 hours is pretty reasonable, keeping in mind that brightness and what you're doing for that time play a major role.

BUILD QUALITY

This is a mixed bag. As noted the screen is the low point of the device. It isn't so terrible that the device isn't usable, but it is pretty bad. If you can live with the C720, you can live with this, but you won't like it.

The Stream 11 comes in at under 3 lbs of weight (2.8 lbs), feeling just a bit heavier than my C720. Heavy compared to modern 10" tablets, but still relatively light.

One complaint I have is that this device only comes in two color options, Blue or Magenta. While I like the blue - it looks better in person than it does in pictures - the absence of a neutral color like white, black, or grey is strange. The diminutive size and blue color does make this look more like a young adult toy than a full-fledged Windows 8.1 device.  That said, it is reasonably sturdy in the hand, feeling and looking mostly like a shrunken version of the HP14 Chromebook.

Unfortunately, the trackpad on the HP Stream 11 is NOT on par with the HP14 Chromebook. While the HP14 is a $300-$380 device (depending on specs), I don't think it is unreasonable to expect the touchpad to be on the same level of quality as the HP14 or C720. It isn't. I've used worse, but I definitely will prefer a mouse with this, whereas on my Chromebooks I think of a mouse as totally optional.  Through use, I've gotten better with it, but at first I was having a very hard time just dragging and dropping files into folders, for instance.

The keyboard pretty much feels like a shrunken HP14 Chromebook keyboard. Keys are a bit squishy and don't have a ton of travel, but it is stated as 97% full sizes and my WPM was about the same as usual.

EXTRAS

On its own, this is a pretty compelling device for $200, but HP throws in some goodies.

You get a one-year subscription to Office 365 Personal (one computer + one tablet). This does not come installed on the device; you get a redemption key that must be used by the end of 2016. I actually love this, as you can redeem the subscription on another device if you choose to do so. This is a $70 value. I'm still debating whether to redeem this key for my Stream 11, so I did not test MS Office, but based on how it runs Google Docs and Sheets, I would expect they'll run just fine provided you don't have a ton of other applications going at the same time.

You also get a $25 Windows App Store gift-card.

Finally, you supposedly get 1 TB of MS Cloud storage for a year, which is pretty crazy if accurate. As I have no need for that yet - I have 150 GB of Drive storage from my Moto X and Chromebooks - I haven't tested it, but it is a very nice add-on.

These offers compare pretty well to those Google gives you with Chromebooks (12 GoGo In-flight passes, 60 days Google All Access Music passes, and 100 GB Cloud Storage for two years).

FINAL THOUGHTS

I'll need to spend some more time with this device before I know for sure how I feel about it, but first impressions have been pretty favorable. I didn't expect it to run Windows 8 so well, or have such a short boot time. The Chrome performance was much better than I'd expected based on what I read elsewhere, and Steam Streaming worked perfectly.

While I still wish there was a neutral color option like Black or Grey on the market, which would make me feel much better about suggesting to grown adults that this is a serious computing device, this is a decent-looking device with build quality and Windows 8 performance above expectations for this price point. For students or those seeking an ultraportable back-up computer, I think you'll be pleasantly surprised with this computer.

If you're thinking about getting an Office 365 Personal subscription anyway, this computer is basically $130, which is an absurd value.

I think 95% of the college students would be happy to have this as their only computer. First, I was little bit skeptical about the performance of the CPU and the lack of the hard drive, but CPU was surprisingly fast and hard drive was a non-issue as I save everything on OneDrive. When I say "CPU is fast," I do not mean that it is as fast as a expensive CPU as I5 or something, but it is fast enough that you don't feel like your computer is lagging on your daily jobs.

This is cheap, light, fast and durable computer.

However, this laptop is not for
- High quality 3D gaming
- Media editing (Photoshop runs fine but I wouldn't do much
- Advanced programming (Visual Studio will fill the hard drive)

Overall, I would recommend this laptop to anyone unless they really need "high performance computer."

Great idea if you really must have a Windows computer. It's good looking and by all accounts sturdy. But I still prefer the Chromebook.
You can run MS Office online apps on the ChromeBook for free without the worry of malware infection that you have with a standard Windows installation. You can also run Google Apps. It's an interesting idea though. Too bad most will slow to a crawl as soon as the user downloads a free email offer.
Which they surely will.

The HP Stream 11 reminds is me a lot of my old HP netbook. My favorite things about this computer is that it's light enough to carry around without the bulk. The machine feels as if it weighs two pounds total. It's about the size of an Amazon Kindle, and easy to slip into a medium sized purse or computer sack with no problem.

One surprise that I had: the laptop is much prettier than its picture on Amazon.com. It's a matted blue with a silver HP logo. The keyboard itself is a bit of a standout. When you open the keyboard, it is almost a sunset-gradient color (with a polka dot tech pattern).  Design is something that matters to me when purchasing a computer, and this one looks much better, and much more elegant that its picture would suggest.

Since this is a low-price machine, some of the high-end features are missing. There is no CD ROM/DVD player. The screen isn't a touch screen, and the mouse is not as sensitive as some high-end machines. The quick access buttons are also under the function keys too. Additionally, there isn't a keypad on the machine. It does have SD-ROM card slots, and USB ports, to use with your machine, as well as a headphones port.

My ultimate disappointment with the HP Stream 11 is not it's design or features; which I was satisfied with. My main problem is with the operating system that it uses. Although I like the design of this laptop, I don't like the Windows 8.1 operating system which is the antithesis of intuitive. Windows 8.1. was one of the reasons my new Dell laptop became a pretty paper weight, rather than being used daily.

Although you can access some operating system functions through going through the control panel, there are other functions that you cannot uninstall from your desktop (some of the bloat ware). Additionally, it basically forces you to get a Microsoft Account before setting up your desktop, and if you do not uninstall some anti-privacy features, advertisers and other third-party individuals will have access to your desktop. Savvy users should go through the custom install and ensure that these third-party groups do not have access to your computer. Another draw back for this machine is that it has a subscription to Office (for a year) rather than the ability to own the software outright.

I plan on installing Windows 7 (and when all the kinks are worked out) Linux Mint onto my new HP computer. I am going to use this primarily as a machine that I take to work, to write my articles on when I'm at work.  I'm really happy with the HP Stream, overall, but I plan to use a different operating system with it in the end. Three and a half stars.

Hi everyone, I received the blue Steam 11 directly from HP today. I have only spent a few hours with it but I thought I would post a quick review.  It seems like a lot of computer for the money, it has a very solid feel. The only complaint I have is my touchpad has a slight rattle, when you tap it lightly you can hear and feel a rattle.  It is hard to explain but it does not have the same tight, spring-loaded feel of other laptop touchpads I have used. I usually use an external mouse so it should not be an issue.

I did not test performance other than playing some YouTube videos at 720p and the performance seemed good. I plugged in a 23 inch LCD TV to the HDMI port and that looked very good and the audio played through the TV speakers automatically and sounded good. I checked the disk with the Windows Disk Management Utility and it shows it has a 29 GB Hynix HBG4e with a 260 MB EFI partition, 21.54 GB NTFS C: drive (4.3 GB used, 17.2 GB free) and a 7.20 GB Recovery partition.

Changing the BIOS to legacy boot mode, I attempted to boot Mint Linux 17 from a USB stick (and also an external DVD drive) and it booted very slowly, I never got it fully booted.  It kept displaying "Buffer I/O error on device mmcblk0rpmb" errors which I googled and found is a known issue with the latter Linux kernels and newer eMMC flash devices.  There is apparently a kernel patch for it. I also got these same errors attempting Mint 16 but when I dropped back to Mint 15 with the 3.8.0-19-generic kernel, it booted fine.  Unfortunately the Realtek RTL8723BE Wifi card was not recognized and the touchpad did not work.  I will continue to work on these issues and report back my progress.

UPDATE 11/2/14:

After some experimentation, the best Linux distro I have found so far for the Stream 11 seems to be the newly released Ubuntu 14.10 with its 3.16 kernel which recognizes the Stream's Wifi and touchpad.  It does still have the problem with the slow boot up (about 8 minutes compared to over 2 hours for Mint 17) where it displays "Buffer I/O error on device mmcblk0rpmb" and "stdin: I/O error" errors.  After boot up, other operations trying to read the disk are also slow.

The problem appears to be the Hynix HBG4e drive's 4 MB Replay Protected Memory Block (RPMB) partition which mounts as /dev/mmcblk0rpmb. It uses different commands and the Linux kernel is unable to access it. There are some kernel patches available that prevent the kernel from attempting access but I have not tried that yet. The partition is apparently used to store DRM and/or OEM licensing keys.

UPDATE 11/5/14:

I installed Ubuntu Mate 14.10 64-bit to the hard drive as a dual boot with Windows 8.1 and it seems to be working well. It has solved (or at least greatly reduced) the problem with the RPMB partition delaying booting and disk operations.  I wrote up the procedure I used:

 Dual Boot Ubuntu 14.10/Windows 8.1 Install Procedure for the HP Stream 11 laptop:

 - Download the Ubuntu 14.10 64-bit ISO image and burn it to a USB drive, (the 32-bit images cause issues with UEFI and the grub boot loader). I used Ubuntu Mate but other flavors such as Kubuntu and Xubuntu should work fine also.

 - In Windows, use the Disk Management utility to shrink the C: drive to make room for Ubuntu, I shrank mine by 10 GB.

 - In the BIOS, leave the legacy support boot option set to the default "Disabled".

 - Turn the computer on and when you see the backlight, press the F9 key to display boot options and select the USB drive. Select "Install Ubuntu", there is a 2-3 minute delay due to the RPMB partition issue, (press ESC if you want to see the errors).

 - When the Install screen appears, select language and add a Wifi connection if you have it. I selected both options presented here: "Download Updates while Installing" and "Install this third-party software".

 - There was a 8 minute delay here while it read the disk configuration due to the RPMB partition issue.

 - For Installation Type, pick "Something else".  It should now show the free disk space you created in Windows, I created a 8 GB ext4 partition mounted on root "/" and a 2 GB swap area partition.

 - Highlight the ext4 partition and click "Install Now", it will confirm that it will write changes to the disk configuration.

 - If you want to only run Ubuntu and not Windows, you can wipe the entire eMMC drive clean (including the 7 GB recovery partition) by selecting the default "Erase Disk and Install Ubuntu" option. It will do the partitioning for you if you want by creating a 512 MB EFIboot, 26.73 GB ext4, and a 1.89 GB swap partition.  (You might want to first create recovery media in Windows using the Recovery Manager utility and a 8 GB USB drive so you can restore back to the factory configuration if needed.)

 - While the installation runs, it will prompt for time zone, keyboard, user credentials and computer name.

 - When it finishes, reboot and you should see the GRUB Boot Menu allowing you to boot into either Ubuntu or Windows (if you left Windows in place on the drive).

When Ubuntu runs for the first time, the touchpad clicks may be disabled depending on the Ubuntu flavor installed so you need an external mouse to navigate to System => Control Center => Mouse and select "Enable Mouse Clicks With Touchpad". There may be a way to do this from the keyboard also.

There may also be an issue with the touchpad and mouse freezing so you need to run the Software Updater to get the latest updates and then reboot and it should hopefully fix this.  (It was fixed on Ubunbu Mate but not on Ubuntu Gnome when I tried it.)  The RPMB partition issue also seems fixed at this point, I installed GParted and it came up quickly without any delay.

Hope this helps.

Speed

This is a Celeron processor, but running on flash/ssd hardware makes it pretty zipping. It's definitely not a workhorse but if you just need a kick-around laptop to bring with you to work/starbucks/wherever else, it can do the basics and then some. Wireless AGN speeds can handle just about as much as you can throw at it.

Display

You get a pretty decent and vibrant 1366x768, which can play 720p content easily (720p is 1280x720). On this small a screen and the distance you'll likely be sitting from it, it would be extremely unlikely you could noticed the difference from 1080p. Viewing angles are pretty decent vs similar sized laptops I've seen. If you'd complaing about not having 1080p or 4k, why are you looking at this laptop?

Quality / Price

Quality is pretty decent for a tiny $200 laptop - probably more than I would have expected. I'm disappointed that the touchpad can only be button-pressed in the bottom half (rather than anywhere on the touchpad).  Still better than the old-fashioned 2 separate buttons that plague most Windows machines, but definitely not as good as the apple-esque full touchpad. But a reasonable trade-off for a $200 laptop. Battery life is fantastic.

Software

It comes with Windows 8.1 (non-RT), which is great. The flash-based storage lends to a pretty slick interface. Unfortunately it's also plagued by a ton of included bloatware, such as:
Various HP junkware
Apple Bonjour (spyware in my opinion)
Dropbox
TripAdvisor
Amazon
McAfee LiveSafe
Weather Channel
"Snapfish"
"MySMS"

Privacy

If you read the HP Terms-of-Service (which you wouldn't get if you bought an Apple or direct-from-Microsoft product), it collects "anonymous technical information related to HP Software and your HP Product". HP and included third-party software will also collect personal information including your IP address and anything you include in the registration. You can't opt-out of it, so this is a nice middle-finger to the buyer. You can't re-install the OS thinking you'll get a clean slate; you just get a refresh of Win8.1 with all the bloatware back. So you can either uninstall the junk, app by app, or try to extract the serial number and re-install from a fresh 8.1 key. It's not listed on any product information or a sticker on the back, so it's a hassle.

Overall a decent product, decent battery life, with some significant trade-offs.

In many ways the HP Stream 11 is a better buy than the more expensive HP Stream 14. This 11 inch model costs $100 less, yet has the same overall screen resolution as the larger device. The 11 also has a better performing Intel processor, an N2840 Celeron, that does better with core browsing and computing tasks. And if that's not enough, the 11 comes with a one year subscription to Office 365 so that a full version of Office can be installed on the 11. The 14 does not come with the Office subscription. Like the 14 there are some limitations. The device is limited to 2 gigs of non-expandable RAM and has a very small 32 gig solid state disk that's also not accessible. Although 32 gigabytes is double the storage available on most Chromebooks, Windows and its applications require much more disk space to operate. Despite its limitations this is a very capable and VERY affordable Windows PC that is designed to go head-to-head with Chromebooks. In fact it has most of the same guts as a Chromebook but runs Windows 8.1 instead. I am excited about the current state of the low-end market. We are getting great capable PCs at very low prices. For once it's nice to see some real competition at this end of the market.

This little laptop is well worth the money. I bought it to work with it in remote Namib Desert, thinking it would be sturdy and enough to get me through basic internet access for a few years. Despite some problems with memory (sometimes have to clear out useless software, to make space for updates), it has been pretty much the best value-for-money technology purchase I've ever made. Connects easily to wifi (even dodgy sources), works well with large files and programmes, and is everything I've needed - with the essential addition of a micro-SD card, where I store all of my docs, music, etc. I followed previous reviews' advice and got a wireless mouse to use, which I prefer to the occasionally less-than-accurate track pad. Woudl buy it again, especially for traveling light with effective minimalist tech on hand.

Be aware of current and upcoming space limitations.  Lots of reviews here are from a few years ago when Win 8.1 was in use.  The hard drive is only 32GB and usable space is around 28GB.  Win 10 uses about 20GB of space.  That leaves maximum of 8GB for any non-OS programs (thats if you remove all the crapware and keep all your media on an SD card).  Next bloated update for Win 10 is "creator" update which will take another 4GB away.  Remember, external storage is just for media-pics/movies/books.  You need space on your hard drive for system programs and soon there will not be any left.  Why HP still sells with such a small hard drive is a good question and one they avoid by blaming Microsoft.  But regardless of blame, if you don't have space for your operating system, the machine won't work. Also, the hard drive and RAM are soldered onto motherboard so they can't be replaced or upgraded.

I've been using this since November 2015 after my old laptop broke, as I just needed something to bring around with me for presentations and trips (I have a desktop for my 'heavy work'). I never planned on doing anything more than doing basic tasks (internet, Skype, etc.) and for that it handles extremely well. Every now and then it'll slow down, but I can't complain for the price that I paid for it. The storage is kind of a problem, but I've gotten accustomed to using the cloud, but there is an microSD card slot to expand the storage. Speakers aren't anything fantastic, but the battery life is, and I never have to worry about it dying for a while. The computer is also pretty durable, I'm not afraid to drop it or such. I like the finish on the exterior of it, and the grips on the bottom of the computer are useful to have. Keys are nothing special, and the trackpad is a tiny bit small. Overall, I really can't complain for the price that I paid for it. This thing is great for basic tasks and I've never run into any real problems with it, and if this thing ever does die on me, I'll definitely be buying the successor.

I've had this lil laptop about a year and it works well for internet browsing, word processing and basic computing. I see a lot of reviews with 1 or 2 starts but it seems that they were expecting way too much. 2GB RAM means you can't have a dozen programs running at once. So if you're the kind of person who likes to have a ton of internet tabs open with a few PDF's , word docs, a chat session, etc. then YOU WILL HAVE PROBLEMS WITH IT RESPONDING SLOWLY. Do not buy this if you needs a serious workhorse PC. It's definitely not a gaming PC either. You can optimize it by deleting the bloatware the comes per-installed and there's an SD slot to expand the memory for pics, videos, music & documents. I recommend this PC for one who's on a budget that don't require much multitasking. It does handle light multi-tasking pretty well. Like I use it for my online college studies and typically open 3 to 5 browser tabs, stream a video lecture up to 90 minutes, have 2 word docs and 2 or 3 PDF's open all at once no trouble at all. I also use it to stream Netflix and Amazon music or videos when I'm not doing schoolwork. For under $200 it's an attractive PC that comes with 1year of MS Office 365, and Windows 10.

Like others have said, it's really slow, even for just writing papers and browsing the internet. The keyboard isn't good either in that it doesn't have a nice feel and also, for me, the spacebar sticks all the time. The laptop is so slow that my text is often behind and I have to go back and correct what I wrote after it catches up (and also add spaces where the spacebar stuck, which is practically every other word). I bought mine almost two years ago and it is still in nearly new condition, but only because I rarely use it  and I only use it if I'm really desperate. Well, I can't say that either. Once it was so bad and I needed to have something typed up that I switched to my phone, opened up Google docs, and started using voice-to-text, which worked much better and I had far less text to correct. I really regret not using it enough when I first purchased it to notice any of these issues because now I'm stuck with this piece of junk. This was the first HP product I've ever bought and now that I'm looking for a new laptop, I'm wary of purchasing anything else by them. Kind of looking at the Dell Latitudes.

When I bought this computer over a year ago, I was switching from a much larger, bulkier laptop, so this one's lighter weight and more compact size were a relief. I knew the RAM wasn't uber-great so I added a micro card to hold my media and a couple of programs that I use on a regular basis. That seemed to do the trick. Until the most recent Windows 10 update came out. I've removed everything I can; I've even tried putting the Windows 10 upgrade on the micro card - and my work is still frequently interrupted by messages that the update can't be installed because there's not enough memory. Kinda getting sick of that. If I have more than a couple of tabs open in my browser, or several documents open at the same time, Windows starts nagging me shut things down because - guess why? - the computer is low on memory. Sure, I love the color of this laptop, but if I had it to do over again, I would get something that could actually handle what I need it to do.

I have a 128 gig micro SD card installed, but unfortunately Windows will not allow updates or apps to be installed to the SD card. So the SSD has the operating system and Chrome - that's it - and the SD card has all my files (documents, photos, videos, etc.), and I'm hobbling along, running disk cleanup between crashes while waiting for a new computer to be delivered in a couple days. I purchased this laptop for my girlfriend who has return to college. It has been a fiasco almost from the beginning. The lack of storage and ram I knew when I bought it. The unexpected problems popped up when Office 365 suddenly quit. It turns out the licence was for 1 month trial rather than a year. Called up microsoft to fix the problem. while they reloaded 365 several bits of malware slipped in (past the also included McAfee) including 4 trojans and 1600+ PUPs. It took Malwarebytes to find and fix them and CCleaner to fix the registry. Also at the same time, the WiFi range suddenly dropped to less than 20 feet in line of sight of the router. As this all happened with the reloading of Office365, we have assumed that this is a MS problem. We've spend hours on the phone, chatting with them and working on our own with no progress. Today the tech support guy tried to update windows 10. Found out the update required 40GB of hard disk space! That alone makes no sense, let alone that the hard drive on this machine is 32GB and could accomodate it. Image that one of the world's most respected PC manufacturers and the makers of the worlds largest operating system can't manage to match the hard drive size to the operating system requirements. At least we were able to update all the drivers (including for the network adapter). I guess I'll look for answers from independent sources on the internet, since the makers of the operating system have none to offer. Girlfriend is ready to chuck the thing and get an Apple.

Bought for my wife for use in college courses. It is an alright laptop if you don't need to do much and most of your use is in the cloud. The windows version on it wasn't the best utilization of resources and felt kind of buggy and extremely slow. When the wife picked it out, she didn't know much about drive sizes, so she didn't think twice about a 32GB SSD.
I can expect the slow processor and ram because of the type of laptop it is, but the size of the SSD is just ridiculous even if you mainly do cloud data.  32GB sounds adequate until you factor in that windows 8.1 takes up almost 18GB of space. It really isn't enough space left with everything else to do much with it.

32GB SSD
------------------------
18GB windows 8.1
4GB of bloatware HP software and addons
2GB of caching space to help the woefully inadequate ram
----------------
24GB - 32GB = 8GB left for actual use.

Once you install a document suite like Microsoft 360 or live, you really only have like 5GB to work with, which is definitely not enough for a college student.

I recommend you do not regard any reviews giving this product above 3 stars. It is likely that those who made such high reviews only had the laptop for a few days. I'm not going to sugarcoat it; it's a piece of crap. It's a $100 laptop, and you are going to receive a computer worth $100. Here is a list of my personal complaints...keep in mind, I've had the computer for about a year and a half now:

-Storage: absolutely atrocious. In the first few days of owning it, I already had issues with running out of space. I've gone around the issue with using flash drives, but I've already gone through 2, and I'm no longer willing to buy anymore or purchase an external hard drive.
-Unfixable driver issue: I've had a driver issue for a few months now where I can no longer use the trackpad. I've tried everything I can on my own. I've just had to resort to using keyboard shortcuts and a wireless mouse.
-Overheating: this laptop does not have a fan. I repeat, this laptop DOES NOT have any sort of cooling mechanism. It gets extremely hot, and, as a result, one of my USB ports melted a little and is sometimes unusable. I'm actually surprised the whole thing hasn't caught on fire yet.
-Memory: also deplorable. My laptop can no longer perform regular scans, leaving it vulnerable to malware. Other applications that need to be automatically updated regularly also cannot do so.

The ONLY reason I am giving this product 2 stars rather than 1 is due to the price. If you're stingy and are only willing to put $100 into a brand new laptop, you're going to get what you pay for: absolute garbage. As a result, the price is fair.

I've had this for about a week and a half, and have used it almost every day. I teach college writing, so I wanted a smaller computer to grade papers (offline if necessary), create word documents, answer emails, and occasionally watch YouTube videos.

This certainly does everything I need it to, and I've overall happy with this inexpensive laptop.
A few notes:
-The bottom runs warm, but not actually hot, since there is no fan.
-the battery hasn't died on me; I've used it for up to 4 hours in a day.
-I don't recommend installing Chrome browser. When I did this, my computer slowed significantly. There were significant delays in word processing every few seconds, where I would not be able to type. I found that Chrome kept running background programs. Since it's a smaller computer with less memory and overall power, those background programs really messed things up. When I uninstalled Chrome and installed Mozilla Firefox instead, the speed problems resolved.
-I haven't noticed a huge problem with sound, as others have, but it's not the best quality--it IS an inexpensive, small computer after all.
-My keys don't stick and the keyboard is quite comfortable for me to use, writing 4-5 pages at a time.

I highly recommend getting a microsd card for storage and not downloading anything heavy software wise. No photoshop, no gaming, probably not even Skype. It lags sometimes and is slow in general, works best when I keep it under 5 tabs on a web browser. If you are anything above broke and in desperate need of a computer, choose another laptop.

I got this computer to replace my Chromebook after that device's touchpad stopped working. I love this little computer!! However, I do use it like a Chromebook and save everything to my google cloud, so no issues with storage space.

Similar to Chromebook:
Cheap
Almost no storage space
Cute and light
Keyboard feels nice
Holds a charge for a long time

Advantages over Chromebook:
Download plugins so I can access work files from home
Can connect to my non-google printer
Has a delete button (delete on Chromebook is ALT+back)

Disadvantages to Chromebook:
Dealing with windows
Anxiety about deleting excess junk software

Overall, the inability to print or connect to work software was a deal breaker for my little Chromebook.  For me Chromebook was a fun learning experience. You don't need to save everything to your hard drive, and windows is an unnecessary evil. This PC was the best of both worlds. Exactly what I was looking for.

Overall, I am very happy with this purchase, for the price it is a great laptop for everyday uses.

Also it comes with a year of free Office 365 which is great for all the work I do in college. This laptop does do some gaming, but I would not recommend to clutter this computer with a ton of It. Streaming works well with Netflix and YouTube. Also the quality of the sound is pretty good! Also the brightness adjustment is perfect. The battery life is a big pro because it last 7+ hours. Meaning I could use the laptop all day without using a charger. Only thing I do not like is that the keyboard does not light up, but like I said, for the price you pay for what you get. I bought model 11-R014WM but not from Amazon.  I considered a Chromebook, but wanted to use this for work when I travel.  The HDD is 32Gb of eMMC of which about 16 was available.  This model came with Windows 10 installed.  This was the difference for me.  Windows versus Android.  If all I was going to do was browse web sites, either would have been fine.  But with Windows 10 on it, I am able to do everything I could on my main computer.
In addition, I tend to play World of Warcraft in my off-hours.  Wow requires 45Gb of disk to be installed.  So I bought a 64Gb SD card and inserted it in the Stream.  I installed the application there.  Posts from other users say it will not work and that you need an external SSD connected to the USB 3.0 port.  I can tell you this is not true.  OK, I did turn some of the Video settings down, but the game runs fine.

This model comes with a 802.11n wifi card.  Therefore, don't go looking to connect to a 5g wireless connection as it is not supported.  But let's face it, I had Fios 30/30 at my old home (moved in June 2016).  I now have Comcast with 75/10 speeds.  Either way, a wireless "N" adapter is more than enough.

I've gotten 2 of these because I needed a computer quick and cheap.  It works well and does everything it should but both I had ended up having major screen issues without being dropped.  One the backlight refused to work on and the other suddenly turned multiple shades of black and gray.

I really like the HP Stream. I previously had an old Gateway that was made in 2008 running Windows Vista, so I really needed and upgrade. Since I didn't really have a big budget for a laptop, I started to look for cheaper laptops. My friend then told me about his new laptop, the HP Stream. He talked about how it was so portable and light, and it was completely fanless and ventless! It even had an SSD! I decided to buy it, and when I got home, (I bought it at Walmart) I opened up the box and was very pleased. I liked the color of the purple, and I loved how it included a USB 3.0 port, as well as an older USB port. It ran Windows 10, which was a massive improvement from Windows Vista. It had 2 GB or RAM, which was also an improvement, and it had a nice 1.60 GHz processor. It also included a 32 GB solid state drive, which was a very large improvement from the hard drive that was in my old laptop. I didn't really like using the trackpad, but that wasn't a problem since I had already purchased a wireless USB mouse.

All in all, I love my laptop, and it works fine for what I wanted it for. I use it for light gaming and schoolwork.

Chose this based on previous experience with HP products being robust and reliable. And it seemed a good choice - for about a week. Don't let it do HP updates, especially if you're using a browser at the same time.  My daughter was working in Google Drive (Chrome) when she got an alert saying the laptop needed to install updates. Not Windows updates - no, these were for the backup software HP puts on their machines, and the alert comes complete with orange exclamation points, to give it a sense of urgency. It was a legitimate update - for those who think it was a malware issue. It's HP's "helper" applications.  She okayed the update and went back to work.  Or tried to. As soon as the install process got underway, the browser slowed and became unresponsive. She asked me to take a look. Chrome was  frozen and wouldn't close. Task manager wouldn't open. The updates were also frozen. Then we saw the 'restart' image. We thought "Good -  it'll OK after restarting" - but it never restarted. The swirling 'restarting' graphic just stayed until the screen went dark. Power button remains lit, but the computer doesn't do anything. It's a day later, and we've still got a black screen and a lit power button. Unit is sealed, so we can't try the old-fashioned fix of disconnecting the battery to force a restart. Ctrl-Alt-Delete, holding the power butting - nothing has any effect. It's bricked. They need a 'reset' switch like an old calculator. Or they need to build their products properly. My daughter liked it (while it lasted), but Amazon didn't offer a replacement - only a refund.

UPDATE: Cycling the power is the fix for this problem, you just can't do it easily. While boxing the unit for return a day and a half after the issue described above, I noticed the power light had finally gone out (the battery had run down). I plugged the computer in and, after a minute, was able to start it.  One star added, as it didn't stay dead.

Hard pressed to find a positive about this model, which I purchased locally from a major retailer. If it worked long enough to get the bloatware out, maybe I could have improved the performance but mine failed... and quality (or lack of) is one of the cons. Let's take a look at the pros and cons on this laptop...

Pros: Compact and lightweight is a major plus. The blue finish is a turn-off but looks a lot better in person (and when open) and is also easy to spot and keep an eye on - consider these vivid colors a theft deterrent. Keyboard feel is very intuitive - had no issues fresh out of the box with setup typing. Touchpad is 2 finger scroll - you move both fingers vs. keep one stationary and move the other. Display is bright and clear, obviously limited in resolution but acceptable. Takes a microSD card for storage of music / pictures / documents. Can't vouch for battery life as mine failed before a single charge could be used, which takes us to the down sides...

Cons: Just not powerful enough to run Windows 10 - just can not do it. These specs would make for a great Chromebook, but this just chokes beyond words for even basic email and browsing. Truly dissapointed as I wasn't expecting much and received even less performance than my limited expectations. Note that I purchased this to replace a Chromebook, which was FAST but I am simply away from WiFi too much to have a Chromebook work for me. I can not vouch for the battery life as I did not get a single charge worth of use before mine failed. Flickering display, keyboard hanging up (I suspect a touch-pad issue caused the keyboard problem) - well it is going back,

Overall, I am dissapointed. I see these as refurbs and understand why! The build quality is just not there. I can't recommend this laptop simply as the reliability is really questionable. This may be a laptop that dies before it becomes outdated.

I was swayed by the low price of this machine but really wish I'd done more research first. I don't like it.
First, the few positives:
It's very lightweight and it comes in a pretty color. The screen is bright and clear. Start up was very easy.
It goes downhill from there. I only needed this thing to do a few basic functions. Surf the web, play the occasional youtube video, and be the interface between my camera and the web when I travel and take photos, which I then need to upload to social media or online storage. It's kind of amazing how badly it performs at these tasks.  The biggest issue is that it only has 32 GB of memory and Windows 10 and all the stupid apps take up nearly HALF of it. The machine runs slow from the outset and didn't really improve even after I went in and deleted as much crap as I could. With so little available memory and already poor performance, I'm going to have to store all my files in a back up drive. Forget downloading a few movies to take on the airplane. And here's the kicker: YOU CAN'T UPGRADE IT. Neither the memory nor the RAM is upgradable in this machine, which is OBNOXIOUS.
Here's another thing I find annoying: it has a micro SD slot but no standard SD slot. Why???  My camera uses a standard SD. I have no devices that use a micro SD. I don't know why you'd have one and not the other.
Lastly, the touchpad is not great. A light tap does not suffice to select something - you really have to tap it HARD. And sometimes even that doesn't work.

I bought this knowing most of the limitations for it, however I have three problems with the laptop. Here are the three problems:

1. The laptop seems incompatible with UEFI USB boot. If you want to boot up linux/unix onto this laptop, then you are out of luck.

2. The RealtekRTL8723BE wifi adapter does not have "Microsoft Hosted Virtual Adapter" in the network devices under device manager. I have had  no success with my attempts to start a host network via command prompt.

3. The track pad is hard and has a bad response to tapping in substitution for pressing down on it. Within the first hour my fingers were aching from pressing down to left-click on the trackpad.

***For the average user, 2 out of 3 of these problems may not be in issue.***

I purchased this laptop 8 months ago, in January 2016, primarily based on the recommendations here on Amazon. I'll be blunt and say that disappointed is an understatement. As others have mentioned, the bloatware and junk that comes installed on the laptop slow down performance considerably, even if you have zero files you need to save locally. I will admit, however, that I haven't worked to remove all the bloatware and reinstall Windows as some others have. (In my mind, you shouldn't have to spend 2 hours configuring a brand new computer just so it works faster.)

And yes, you're encouraged to use the Microsoft cloud service to save your files, but heaven forbid you prefer to use systems like Evernote or Dropbox. By the time you install their desktop software, you're at 98% of your drive's capacity (literally). Plus, who should have to expand the memory of a new computer simply to work on Word docs and surf the web? My phone and tablet are more reliable and faster, even when everything is on my secure home wi-fi.

Best of all, the internal battery completely crapped out and died this week. The computer simply will not work unless it's plugged in, and every boot up gives me a DOS screen telling me to contact HP because the battery won't charge.

No thanks. I'm cutting my losses and going back to a lower-end Lenovo with an internal hard drive and substantial memory. It's only about $70 more, and at least then, I'll be able to do things like write and record podcasts on my computer (and not wait 10 seconds for a web page to load.)

This laptop offers a lot for the price. I recently bought this laptop for someone and had the pleasure of using it for a week and a half.

The build:
The stream 11 has a good and solid build for $200. The outer shell is a matte smooth plastic the doesn't attract fingerprints like other shiny/glossy laptops in this price range. The HP logo in the middle adds a nice contrast but can be destracting when sitting I high lighted places.

The internals:
The stream has a Intel Celeron and 2 gigs of ram, witch I found were good for browsing the internet, sending emails, and streaming YouTube. However when I was streaming a YouTube video in 720 p while reading a e-book and editing a document on Microsoft word, the video started to get choppy and the typing input was delayed. The internal storage on the model I bought was 32gb, this was a lowered to about 19 GB when windows was fully updated and installed. The 19gb was usable for storing documents, pictures, and low quality video. You wouldn't want to install bulky programs like Photoshop on this as it would take up too much memory and and would run slow due to the 2 gigs of ram. However I bought a 16 gig SD card for 10 bucks to add some storage just in case.

Externals:
The HP stream has a 1366x768 screen that doesn't look bad for its price. However the screen is considerably dim making it hard to use in bright environments. The keyboard is respectable for $200, but is quite mushy and has low key travel. The track pad is a little laggy but supports Windows 10 multi-gesture functions. The speakers are a reasonable volume but can be quite tinny.

Overall I think this laptop deserves 4 stars as it is affordable and a good gift for children or anybody who doesnt need to do heavy editing or gaming.

I received this little laptop as a gift and the machine itself is really nice. It's lightweight and streamlined and the keyboard has nice action for the style.

The downside is that I received the Windows 10 version. Windows 10 is simply way too much OS for this little machine. I attempted to remove as much bloat as possible and Win10 still occupies a huge chunk of the SSD and wants loads of RAM. As I write this in Chrome with only one tab open it's using 58% RAM. With Amazon, Gmail, and Google Docs, open I'm hitting a steady 83% RAM. I know Chrome can be a hog but those are pretty typical cloud work apps and I don't even have Slack or Telegram open yet.

Since my personal intended use for this machine is cloud work and webdev I am seriously considering to wipe it and install Ubuntu or Debian, if I'm feeling adventurous, or invest in a copy of Windows 7.

So if you are considering this machine get the Windows 8.1 version and follow the other review here that explains how to remove a lot of the crapware - it's really useful. Don't get the Win10 version or upgrade to Win10! Otherwise, it's a great little laptop for the price range.

Pros
1. COST: I was able to get my Stream 13 for $169.99 on eBay, since it is used. Even the new ones are still a great price compared to most laptops
2.  SIZE: This laptop is pretty thin and light which means its super portable. We had another HP laptop that was bulker and weighed more making it not so fun to take around. This fits perfectly in my little backpack, and will be easy to take to and from school when I need to.
3. COLOR: Mine is in Orchid Magenta which I think it absolutely beautiful and fun
4. FREE OFFICE 365: This comes with a free year of Office 365 Personal, which saved me $70.
5. BATTERY: This battery has done amazing so far. Ive been watching Netflix, playing a few games, and watching YouTube videos for hours. (Starting using the laptop around 9:45am and its now 5:17pm and the battery is currently at 40%)
6. FEEL: This laptop feels great to hold and doesnt feel cheaply made.
Cons
1. STORAGE: One obvious con is the fact this computer only has 32 GB of storage. That isn't a huge problem for me considering I usually don't store my photos, videos, or music on my laptops. I also have a 32 Gb Micro SD card.
2. TRACK PAD: Ive read mixed reviews on this, but for me it isn't really a problem (I use a mouse when I can) but the track pad can occasionally be annoying. Sometimes itll swipe threw the things I have open.

I'm reporting on an amazing recent service experience involving both HP and Microsoft.  We converted upgraded several of these from Windows 8.1 to Windows 10, and lost the touchpad functionality in all of them.  Web postings showed no solution, with folks just giving up.  My first call to HP told me it was a known Windows 10 problem, call Microsoft.

I called Microsoft, and Kate spent almost an hour with me diagnosing the issue, and then suggested we get HP on the phone again.  So we did, and Rahul from Bangladore got involved.  He decided it was an HP problem, and we let Kate go back to other customers.  Rahul spent about 3 hours with me and via remote access was able to diagnose and fix the problem, explaining everything he was doing in perfect English and computer science terminology (I'm an electrical engineer).  And helped point the way to fixing the other machines, too.

Love the HP Streams, and as of now love HP and Microsoft for putting a lot of customer service into a low profit product situation.  Gotta love great customer service!

We own an escape room and we bought this unit for our game master station to interface with our IP PTZ camera.  Once I went through and disabled all the bloat from HP and all the windows 10 memory eaters it performed fine.  Chrome has become a serious memory hog now days so we surprisingly have to stick to IE for our web interface, also the built in timer for windows 10 is a great replacement for trying to run it via built in google timer.  If you've got a grandparent who just wants to send emails, read the news, and do some light MS office work, this is a great choice.

I chose to buy this laptop(s) for one express purpose: writing. I wanted a portable laptop with good battery life and an excellent keyboard (writing, remember?). After doing a lot of research (and I mean, a lot) I decided I would buy an HP Stream 11. I went to the store and actually bought two Stream 11 laptops because there was a 50% discount on the second HP laptop that you buy. This has given me a chance to look at two different physical models and get a clearer idea of shared problems.

SPECS: both my laptops are the 2nd generation (Fall 2015, N3050 1.6 processor) and both came with Windows 10 installed with minimal bloatware, but in my region, they did NOT come with the 1 year of MS Office, so I am not even factoring that into my rating.

BODY: these little laptops are gorgeous. The casings are nice, and the colors are perfect. The blue is bright and shiny, the purple is just the right hue to be attractive and not (too) unprofessional or girly. Either color would be fine for the buyer, just based on your preference.

SCREEN: I've read many complaints about the screen and most are unfounded (maybe the 1st gen Stream was worse). The screen can achieve a good brightness and 11.6 inches really isn't too small to do most single tasks. If your usage depends on having a large screen, then this isn't the laptop for you (unless you plug it into an HDMI tv or monitor), but it's just fine for word processing and not bad when it comes to viewing websites. The resolution is not "premium", shall we say, but it is perfect for a screen of this size. 8-point Times New Roman is readable, just at the edge of being too grainy. Bigger text points are easily read.
  What I particularly like about the screen is the matte-ness of it. I have another HP laptop (Envy) that has a glossy screen. While it seems that glossy screens can be brighter, they can be a real pain when it comes to working in a room where light sources reflect off your screen. For this reason, I really appreciate the matte screen in the Stream 11 and I think it's excellent.

KEYBOARD: The irony that I wanted this for writing. Many reviewers had problems with the keyboard: most common is that the space-bar is unresponsive. Commenters who type "Iamwriting thiswith mynewcomputer, asyoucan tell itdoesn't work whenIpress thespacebar" are not kidding. I was upset that I experienced the same thing with my Stream when I first bought it. It's a shame because, otherwise, the chiclet-style keys of the Stream keyboard are excellent. There is good space between each of them, and the keys are a very nice size, almost the same size as a full-size keyboard and many professional reviewers have listed the Stream keyboard as the best of the sub-$200 laptop market.
  So, about that space bar? It's a PHYSICAL problem with the way that the key is affixed. The severity of the unresponsiveness varies: my blue 11 needed to be pressed at the center with good pressure to register a space, left or right edges of it just wouldn't work; the purple was somewhat better: the center and left side of the space bar both managed to register a space more often than not with normal pressure. Have a laptop tech look at it, if you are having problems, and he'll notice that it's just a problem of how the space bar is mounted. It sucks to have to get a *new* laptop "fixed", though, so if you are averse to that, I can understand. But this is a mechanical problem and once addressed, the space bar works perfectly (you should have been able to tell by now since I am writing on my blue Stream 11). I took a look at mine at home and managed to get it working but I wouldn't recommend anyone do this: you'll probably mess it up and void your warranty for all I know.

TOUCHPAD: No complaints on the touchpad. It does its job. Good size and once you adjust the sensitivity for it to cover more distance with less movement then there isn't much to be fussy about.

PROCESSING POWER: this is not a powerhouse of a laptop, as I am sure you well know. It does basic things and it does them well enough. Some websites don't display as fast as I'd like. Sometimes it becomes unresponsive when a website is too resource-demanding. Most of the time, if you are doing things one at a time, the Stream 11 does a decent enough job. I would have no problem taking this around as my only internet browsing computer, but without a need for heavy graphics, I might not be able to say the same for your needs.

STORAGE CAPACITY: at 32 gb (28.1 recognized on My Computer screen) the internal memory of the HP Stream 11 is nothing impressive, but my experience is not as bad as some reviewers have suggested. While I haven't installed many programs on this laptop, I still have 11 gigabytes of free space on the internal disk. Compared to people who say they couldn't even update Windows any more...I'm just not sure how that has happened to them.
  But if your computer usage involves large data files, you will have to expand the memory (preferably with the Micro-SD card slot) because there is very little that you can do with those 10~11 gigabytes before they finish. It's better to save those for as much system-related use as possible.

BATTERY LIFE: I have not had a chance to really put this laptop to the test when it comes to battery life (full charge, then time how long it actually lasts) but my usage with it has shown me that it is capable of going many hours. Refer to another review if you want details on battery life, but I have not found anything to complain about.

CAM AND MIC: I haven't had any reason to use the camera, but you can be sure it's not that great. The microphones, on the other hand, were surprisingly good, without any static that I could hear from the speakers.

SPEAKERS: Pretty good for a budget computer. They are loud enough and of a decent quality as well.

THE GOOD: for the light-intensity work that I bought this computer for, I have to say that I am absolutely impressed. Affordability, style, versatility, portability; the HP Stream really is a work of art. If this is the only computer you can afford, well, you're in luck. I do not regret my purchase at all.

THE BAD: the keyboard/space-bar problem can be a huge pain. If you are unlucky (and both laptops I bought had bad space-bars) it's likely that you will find yourself with this problem. As I said, this is a mechanical problem and can be fixed by someone who knows how laptop keyboards work. The only other problems are the weak processor and the small hard disk.

Who would I recommend this laptop to? Anyone that is on the go a lot and wants something that is portable and long-lasting, and doesn't have high processing demands (gaming/design/rendering/etc.) Basically, any student who doesn't want to use this for gaming will find great value in it, so would any adult that is fine using the basic functions of a computer and not AutoCAD or some other resource-heavy software.

This computer states that it comes with virus protection. Within minutes of setting it up (literally about 15 minutes after), The computer was riddled with several crippling viruses. I completed the set up and went to download google chrome, my preferred web browser. I somehow clicked on a bogus version of chrome to download, but there were no warnings whatsoever. Nothing came up as suspicious through any virus protection program. The computer was horrifyingly slow afterward, and could not be used to accomplish very simple tasks. I used the computer for a total of 30 minutes or so before I wanted to pull my hair out. I went and opened the virus protection program which was supposedly installed and working, and after a virus scan, there were NO viruses listed. I recognized the problem when two icons for google chrome appeared and were different from one another.  I went back to the link I had used and recognized immediately my mistake. But how did this go unnoticed by the pre-installed virus protection?! It was completely useless and rendered the computer almost entirely useless within minutes. I returned it right away.

UPDATE: I bought this laptop in May and it is now December. What they don't tell you about the 32GB harddrive is that by the time you get it, you will have about 6GB of drive space left.  The catch here is that Windows 10 needs 8GB of free space to make it's update. There is absolutely no way for this Update to take place. Instead, your remaining harddrive space gets filled up with incomplete Windows updates. I now have 1GB of free space left on my computer. I spend more time trying to uninstall programs and clean up space than actually using this laoptop. Video chat of any form (Google hangouts/skype) is impossible. The computer just freezes.

Save your money and DO NOT BUY THIS. It works well for 1 month and is garbage after that. Stay away

They tried over and over again to get my wife to say that she damaged the computer by dropping it or setting something heavy on top, which she did not! I will never buy an HP product again, and I hope you won't either. SHAME ON YOU HP!!

For the last several years, I've used a heavy-duty Alienware gaming laptop for most of my computing needs. However, at a massive 17 inches and weighing something over ten pounds, this computer is understandably massive. That, combined with how expensive it is, made it a very inconvenient thing to bring along with me when I traveled, even if it was a trip by vehicle, but especially if I had to take a flight, as I do rather frequently.

I've learned through experience that when on a vacation or traveling that, if I do happen to get my laptop out, the purposes I most commonly use it for are browsing the internet or maybe working on a novel-- wi-fi in most places is too shoddy to play any of my games, and I'm usually far too occupied to start a session anyway. I also wanted something that I could keep next to the table in my room, to fool around on while watching television before bed.

As such, I was looking for some sort of solution to this issue-- a computer that could do what I wanted to, primarily browsing the internet, but with enough power to simultaneously do that, and maybe have ZenWriter open as well. And this little computer does all of that and more. It's a pleasant and eye-catching color, but more than that, it's incredibly light-- I can fit it into a bookbag of most sizes with relative ease. Because it's got such a light frame, it's no trouble to carry around, and because it's comparatively so cheap to my main laptop, I didn't need to fret about what might happen if it were to get lost on a vacation.

If there's one drawback to be had with this little laptop, it's the hard drive space. By the time I finished installing some programs and bringing some music onto it, I was running dangerously low on hard drive space. However, I expanded it with a 128GB MicroSD card, so that problem was easily solved.

In summation, if you're a power-user like I am, this laptop isn't for you. However, if you're looking for a small laptop to have around to do simple tasks on, somewhere between a tablet and a more serious laptop, you won't find a much better choice.

So let's be honest, it is what it is -- a $200 computer. If you are willing to accept the shortcomings that come at that price point -- it's pretty impressive what they were able to stuff into what is a fun little device. I'm intending to use it as a coffee table computer, and the blue color adds a nice accent. The screen is the old-school matte type. It's reminiscent of the old Apple iBook, except lightweight with a modern OS. A few things, and a few tips: 1) Taking one star off as the device is pretty slow upon first use, and frustratingly so. To the point of almost being unusable. What I surmised is this is due to the amount of crapware that HP bundles in the default image (security suite, etc.). However with a little work this can be fixed. You can try and remove all the crapware but I simply decided to wipe & load a clean install of Windows 10 (read on before you attempt to do this). 2) The Stream comes with 1 free year of Office 365, which is pretty awesome. YOU MUST ACTIVATE/REDEEM THIS VIA THE START MENU FROM THE FACTORY INSTALL. If you do a clean install of Windows, and forget to do this first, you are out of luck! 3) Now, if you decided to wipe & reload Windows, after making sure you activated Windows and Office, use Microsoft's USB creation tool to create a bootable Windows 10 thumb drive. Aaaaand.... you'll find out the Stream will refuse to boot from it. This was a head-scratcher but I finally figured it out (surprisingly couldn't find a solution online). Your bootable USB *must* be formatted with GPT partitioning, and the USB boot volume must be FAT32, and you must boot via UEFI. For the nerds out there you can do this via diskpart.exe and just extract the contents of the Windows ISO to the USB stick. Once you do this, reboot then hit Esc, followed by F9 to boot from USB. 4) It seems to take 64-bit Windows ONLY. Not sure why as I thought I could get a small performance boost from 32-bit Windows (it being a 2GB RAM device and all) but it refuses to boot the 32-bit Windows installer. Perhaps it supports booting from 64-bit UEFI only. Oh well. 5) Once this is all said & done, with a fresh install of Windows it's a pretty awesome device for the price. After loading Win10, while I was searching out missing drivers from HP, lo and behold it loaded all of them automatically from Windows Update in the background. Give it some time & a few reboots but it will find everything. Pretty cool.

Update 10/13/16
Awful laptop. I bought this thing with the intention of using it for my online classes. I didn't care much about RAM and SSD because I have a great desktop for whatever else I need RAM for.

Right off the bat, I realized the computer struggled if I had multiple tabs open on Firefox. It's slightly better with the add on that stops videos from automatically loading and playing. When I'm working on an assignment, I can't work with one tab at a time. Maybe I have high expectations and don't think realistically?

This has been enough of an issue that I opted to look into expansion options, which is insane because I'm just browsing the web. (God forbid if I have Word open too, and trying to flip between that and the browser)

But this laptop is not expandable in any way.

Okay. So now I'm back to figuring out how to free up RAM usage. I disabled everything that came pre-loaded onto the laptop, uninstalled what I could.

Which brings me to my next complaint. You know how irritating it is that cell phones come pre-loaded with apps you can't remove? It's more regulated now, but I remember how infuriating it was to be unable to remove NASCAR garbage from my phones. Microsoft and HP decided to run with that idea though, and my laptop is FULL of crap on the hard drive that I don't have the option of removing, only disabling.

It says 32 GB SSD. However, the usable space is 28 GB. I've only loaded Kaspersky Total Security, Skype and Firefox. The current available SSD I have is 1.48 GB. I don't save pictures, documents, etc to the drive, I use external storage.

I will reload factory installed software today and hopefully get rid of the junk I can't remove myself. I shouldn't have to read Amazon answers and do research on how to make the computer run better, and go through factory resets. This is ridiculous, and in 5 months I haven't had much opportunity to sit down and mess with all this. It's easier to just use my desktop at this point.

However, I have software/driver issues as well, though I hope resetting the system will fix them:

1) I use Skype almost daily, (which runs OK if I'm not trying to use a browser at the same time) and more often than not, I have to restart my computer at some point because the sound becomes distorted. I have the computer on an external cooling fan, so it's not heat related, and this does not happen if I am using my external webcam and mic.

2) Bluetooth does not work for me. Period. It took me upwards of an hour to get my earpiece/mic linked, which was difficult to do because it wasn't a straightforward, basic thing to do. I had to delve kinda deep in the system to figure out how to do it. Once I had it linked, it still didn't connect. Also, despite both the PC and my Galaxy S7 "seeing" each other in the systems via bluetooth, the PC won't link to the phone. I'm unable to move pictures or documents between the devices via cord connection, either (though this could be the phone, and I just got it so I haven't figured out all of its quirks/changes from my Note4.)

3) As always, Java sucks and always has errors, but to be fair I don't think it works how it should on any system, ever. Shockwave also crashes and messes up.

4) Certain actions just don't work. If I click on "disable" on some useless app, it doesn't do anything, but it will for the other apps. The "windows" key to open the menu doesn't always work.

I just opened task manager to see what the current status is of this heap is.

CPU:
1.60 GHz max speed, but is operating at 2.00-2.15 GHz (?)
Utilization is jumping from 50% to 100% and everywhere between every second
77 (!) processes open

Memory
1.9GB usable, 1.7GB currently in use.
1 of 2 slots used.
Committed 2.9GB/3.6GB

Overall, I hate this thing, and deeply regret not spending a little more on a better product. I'll end up resetting to factory settings to get through this term and buying a better computer and handing this to the kids.

At least it connects to my printer through the wireless network. I've had no issues on that front.

After doing some extended research I decided to buy this laptop, seeing it was exactly what I wanted. A budget laptop where I could use Microsoft Word and browse the Internet. I initially was going to get a chromebook, but I decided this was better suited for my needs. I'm a college student, so I needed Word to write essays, as well as short stories (I'm a recreational writer). Everything about this laptop seemed perfect, except the storage space. But I figured since I wouldn't be playing any games or downloading anything, that the very low 32 gb would be fine. However, it's atrocious. Without installing or downloading any apps or programs (other than Microsoft Office) the hard drive is filled to the brim, out of the box. No worries, I'll be saving all my stuff on a flash drive. What's the big deal? There's no longer enough storage space just to update windows. I'm stuck not being able to ever update the laptop unless I buy an external hard drive, which I really don't want to do. What really suck is that so far (after using it for a couple months) the laptop is actually decent. We needed a second laptop for when both of us needed to do work from home at the same time.  We weren't looking for a gaming unit or the latest thing out there, just a basic laptop that would let us connect to the internet easily, work at a decent speed and be able to run basic Microsoft Office programs.  We thought this one was the right one.  Unfortunately we've had continual wireless connectivity issues with it in the five months we've owned it.  All our other wireless devices will connect just fine, but this one continually cannot connect.  It finds my home network, shows a strong signal, but says it cannot connect with no reason given.  I run Network and internet diagnostics and it cannot find a problem.  I restart the computer, does not fix it.  I end up having to call tech and sometime in the half hour call with our trying everything it starts working again.  Tech tries to say it's our router or cable box; but, if this was the case, all our other devices would be having issues as well.  They all work fine when the laptop craps out.  Once it starts working again, it will last a few weeks and then the same issue happens again.  Very frustrating!!  Granted, I could have purchased the extended warranty like I did for our fancier unit, but for such a basic unit I did not think it was necessary and thought by the time it had issues a year or two down the road, we'd replace it.
