01-30-2016 I have had this laptop for a very short time, three days to be exact. So far, I am very pleased with the way that the laptop has been working. The laptop runs pretty fast browsing the web and running programs. Keep in mind when reading these reviews, a good porting of these individuals either don't care to research what they are buying and/or they have no clue about computers. Sure, there are people that have had these laptops fail on them, that is an eventuality. However, many of the reviews talking about the laptop running slow, being bad for gaming (this is just sad), or having bad storage raises a red flag to me. I have been building computers for years and can tell a good review from a bad one. This is all explained later in my review. I will try to continuously update my review as I experience this laptop over the coming months. Hopefully this laptop will continue to impress for a long time to come. Construction/Feel: The first thing that I noticed was that it is very slim and light. It feels like it has been constructed with good material despite it's very affordable price point. The exterior portion of the laptop has a finish that is a little coarse or rough feeling. It is actually nice because you don't feel like it will slip out of your hand and it seems somewhat scratch resistant. That's huge for me as I will be taking this laptop pretty much everywhere including work. The interior aspect of the laptop I made of aluminum with classy etching to it in various shades of blue (purple if you get that color). It looks really nice, I would never have looked at this laptop and thought it was barely above $200. It looks and feels like it was much more expensive than that. The keyboard is designed with the buttons protruding through the aluminum plate which is nice. The buttons are white and textured in a similar way to the exterior of the laptop allowing your fingers to grip nicely as you type. It will be interesting to see how dirty the buttons look after months of use. Hopefully the texture doesn't make it hard to clean. Only time will tell. Anyway, is very comfortable to type with, you could use this laptop for hours without problem. The touchpad feels somewhat bouncy to me, but that's because I am use to a "stationary" touchpad that has buttons at the bottom versus a clicking touchpad. Sometimes clicking seems a tiny bit inaccurate, but it is nothing to really gripe about. It is more likely that I am hitting the touchpad too lightly (I have a very sensitive Alienware laptop). Other than that, this is a very nicely constructed laptop. Battery Life: Another huge part of what makes this laptop so great is the battery life. I have never owned a laptop that can be under constant use and last as long as this. I have literally used this laptop for the last 4.75 hours straight browsing the web, I watched a Jurassic World, and now I am typing a review on a single charge. That's pretty amazing for a 13.3" laptop. According to the battery life indicator (which is actually very accurate unlike some), I still have 30 minutes left with 8% battery life. Right now it is in power saving mode making it last longer than normal. Until it reached 20% battery life (that's when battery saver setting turn on), I have been running it as if it were plugged in with the screen on 100% brightness. At 10% battery life, a warning comes up stating "you might want to plug your laptop in" and at 8% another comes up with a similar statement. If you were running this laptop from the start in battery saving mode, you could probably get a whole lot more use from it. In fact, maybe that will be my next test. Storage: This laptop only comes with 32GB of storage from the factory, this is not a secret and is clearly stated in the product details. It surprises me that people bought this and then give it a one star for storage capability. This situation is easily addressed as you will very soon see. The majority of that storage is used up by a combination of pre-installed programs and of course, the Windows 10 operating system. I have removed a few programs and installed one small movie player program leaving me with only 2.66GB free of 27.8GB. As you can see, there is pretty much nothing left in the way of storage. The first problem is that people don't READ and expect that this laptop (technically a netbook) has tons of storage. Not to be harsh but reading seems to be a diminishing skillset in our society. That's why I went ahead and ordered myself a 128GB micro SD card. That way anything else I may need more permanently can go there instead of on the factory internal storage. You can pick any brand you want, I decided to go with this one because it seems to be the best price for the speed: Silicon Power 128GB up to 75MB/s MicroSDXC UHS-1 Class10, Elite Flash Memory Card with Adaptor (SP128GBSTXBU1V20SP). I have officially been able to install programs on this micro SD card with zero problems. I am not sure why I have seen people say that you can't, because you can. When it comes to more storage capability and INSTALLING PROGRAMS, I went with a 4TB (4000GB) portable external hard drive made by Seagate: Seagate Backup Plus 4TB Portable External Hard Drive with 200GB of Cloud Storage USB 3.0, Blue (STDR4000901). What's nice about this particular hard drive is that it that it is very small, and requires no external power supply, meaning that it is powered via the USB cable connected to the laptop. This is where I store my heavier files such as movies programs. I have seen people say that you can't install any programs on added/external storage. This is not always the case. I just installed a music program on this Seagate external hard drive called Guitar Pro 6 and it runs fine. It doesn't run as fast as it would if I had it on the internal storage, but it does work. I will write the steps down on how to do this below. Another cool thing about the Seagate hard drive is that there are multiple colors to choose from so that you can match it to your laptop. As you can see, storage really isn't something to be concerned about in any respect. If you want more internal storage on a laptop this size expect to spend a couple hundred more on a full-blown laptop. Now on to the computer running slow issues. This issue can have many variables. If you know your computer is clean from malicious software (cause 1), and doesn't have a lot of programs installed that boot up as your computer turns on (cause 2), it is often directly related to storage (cause 3). A computer should have a few GB (preferably more) free to operate at full capacity. Without going into detail, my custom built gaming PC will run slow if I fill the hard drive with the OS on it completely. This is not a problem with the computer, but more so that there is no "breathing room" for the operating system and other components to work. Throw a micro SD card in, make sure you save your files there, and save some room for your operating system. This is the main problem people run into when their computer is running slow and they aren't infested with adware/malware and other infectious programs that automatically run when you turn on your PC. If you have eliminated all of these variables, then you may be unlucky and actually have a hardware problem. ****IMPORTANT**** I have discovered a way to save you 8.9GB of storage instantly and it is very easy. This computer comes with a factory reset that looks to be a way to revert it to the previous version of Windows (8.1). It will automatically delete this after a month of using this laptop. However, you can remove the files right away if you would like. Currently, with Office 365 installed, I have 9.63GB free. Plenty of space for the computer to run efficiently. From this point on, you can use either the added micro SD card for storage or your external hard drive. Keep as much space as you can free on the internal hard drive so that the laptop will run better. Keep in mind that you can use this technique do keep track of storage and delete things you don't need such as temporary files, here is how you do it: 1: Go to the "ask me anything" search box AKA Cortana and type in "storage". 2: Click on "Storage- In system settings" which will have a little gear symbol. 3: Click on "this PC (C:) and let the system load the information 4: Scroll to the bottom of the list and delete the 8.9GB recovery file. 5. Restart your computer, and you will see the space is now free on your hard drive. ****Installing Programs On Your External Hard Drive and Running Them On This Laptop**** 1: Make a folder in your external hard drive. I prefer to name the file "Program Files (x86)" because that is what the file is named where you normally save programs to anyway. 2: Get your program, you need to either have a download code from the internet, or since this laptop has no disk drive, you need an external disc drive to initially install the program you want. Treat it as you are installing anything else you would normally install. 3: When installing the program it will ask you where you want to install it which is set at Drive (C:) Program Files (x86) by default. All you have to do is change the location of the programs installation which now will be on your external hard drive under the new file you named "Program Files (x86)" 4: Proceed with the rest of the install. 5: Repeat these steps for other programs it is literally that easy. You can use this very same method to install smaller programs on your micro SD card as well. I also found out that you can change your storage settings to automatically store apps, documents, music, pictures, and videos to your micro SD card. All you have to do is go to your system settings, storage, and scroll down to the tabs that allow you to change where these files are automatically stored. Easy right? Speakers: The speakers on this laptop are actually surprisingly loud. They certainly are not the loudest on the market, but for what you pay for the laptop, they get the job done. Gaming: If you are seriously considering a laptop like this for gaming, you are in the wrong place. This doesn't have the CPU, RAM, or Processor capable of giving you a good gaming experience. Sure, it will run the simple tablet games such as Angry Birds, but it simply is not designed in any way for AAA gaming. If you want a gaming laptop, be ready to spend well over $1000 for a decent one. That is currently all that I have for now. I haven't been able to use the integrated web cam yet. I will try to get to that soon. Hopefully this review helps someone. This really is a bang for your buck laptop and I am extremely satisfied this far.

After reading the reviews here I was aprehensive but ordered anyway. I am waiting on new Macs to come out but needed something to fill the gap, replacing my old dying HP laptop hardware/heat related issues that may be  by Win 10). I could not resist the price at 179.99. If it doesnt work out, I can donate it to our Cub Scout pack, who needs a limited capability laptop.  You get what you pay for.
Are there storage limitations? Yes - I can keep my files on a home Network Attached Storage (NAS) drive for a while. (I must figure out another backup solution for files. We have several other home computers I might use or i may try out the bundled cloud storage that came with it for a limited time).  I have already researched and it looks like it will accept any size microSD card (greater than the 32GB cited in HP literature). I will also try that as a local storage or backup volume.
Are there RAM memory and CPU speed limitations? Yes - cant do anything about this other than not run many apps/web pages at a time.  I have installed Firefox and opened at least 10 tabs on one of my favorite forums. It took many seconds (maybe 15) to load all the pages but once they loaded, there were no issues reading, scrolling, or switching between tabs. With task mgr running, CPU usage was at 100% for most of the load time but settled down after they loaded.
Despite other reviews, the unit i got did not have much bloatware on it. I installed and ran CrapCleaner first and it only found a couple of items i removed immediately. I left most of the Windows 10 fluff on it thinking i might use it at some point or remove it after a few weeks if i haven't taken the time to learn to use it (I started using Win 10 just a couple of months ago and haven't taken the time to actually learn all the features).
Other concerns: I should have gotten the 13 inch instead of the 11 due to eyesight vs screen area. But I didn't have time to wait on a deal. I increased the font size in Win10 to 125%. The keyboard takes a bit of getting used to becuase your hands are closer together and some keys (like delete and backspace) are not in the usual locations. I don't like the tocuhpad but stopped using it after installing the wireless mouse.  Some Win10 apps cannot be uninstalled (uninstall button is greyed out) using the Win10 normal function. This includes Xbox (I don't game); Windows store, and a few others i cant remember. Im sure there is a way to remove this stuff but when i looked it didn't take up much storage space.
So far i have installed: CCleaner (freeware version); Logitech wireless mouse; Firefox; Thunderbird. Except for speed on the last two, all perform adequately.  I played a youtube.com and played a video and also checked the HDMI port, driving my flatscreen TV. There were no issues. I plugged in an 8GB microSD card that we had around the house. It showed up immedately in Explorer but i haven't used it yet. I only have a few stored emails and NO stored files moved over so far. Using Explorer C drive properties, i have used 15GB of 28GB (only 13GB more availlable.) I have not elected to compress the C drive yet (not sure what the effect noticeable will be on speed, if any).
I like the size and weight (small!) and the case seems comparitively rugged construction. Although i have had few problems ith HD's in the past, i like the SSD instead of an HD. I have already dropped it once with no issues.
I just got this as a college laptop, and I'm loving it! It's very lightweight and easy to carry around. Perfect for lugging around a college campus all day. This is a really nice laptop!

We bought this laptop on 11/29/14 and have used it daily for the past 14 months for websurfing, email, watching videos online.  Out of the box, it had Win 8.1 installed & everything worked great. Wifi connected fine, comfortable keyboard, nice design; the best part is still the looks & color (which is sad, actually).

Within a few months, the Wifi started dropping a lot. We bought a USB wifi adapter and that helped, but the onboard Wifi really should be good enough quality to last.  The keyboard is a pain. It's just not as smooth as other ones. Not sure if it just gets old, but I've never noticed keyboard issues with any of the numerous other laptops we've had.  The computer is sluggish.  We run Avast, Malwarebytes, and Superantispyware regularly and disk cleanup, but it's just too slow.

The biggest issue is lack of storage space! This hard drive is just TOO small for a large operating system like Windows!  (fine with linux)  These streaming laptops should come with a minimum of 64gb hard drive space.  We don't use this to store files such as photos, videos etc. Just Windows, antivirus, and a few programs we use regularly.  We can't even load Office because there isn't enough space (after cleaning the disk via Windows and Clean Master). If you do a Google search, some people can't even update Windows or upgrade to Windows 10 because of the lack of space.

We are getting a micro SD card (it does have a micro SD slot) to keep in the slot all the time so we can transfer as much off of the SSD as we can eg if we can use the micro SD for antivirus, Office etc that may help.

Next time I buy a streaming laptop, I will look for a different brand (all our HPs have been problematic) and something with a bit more storage.

Edit:  Office 365 can NOT be stored on an SD card. Unlike previous versions of Office, there is no option where to install.  We added a 32gb micro SD card, moved our antivirus software & other programs onto that, and we were able to install Office 365. However, there is very little storage space left.

I've gone through a few laptops over the last number of years, with mixed results and experiences. In the past I have had decent luck with HP, so when I needed something inexpensive quickly to keep up with school work I jumped at the chance to try this machine out. I have been disappointed. Really the only reason I would even give this thing two stars is that it was cheap and readily available. I guess you do get what you pay for.
Less than ten days after receiving this thing it crashed during an update and completely locked out all controls. It had to be returned to HP to have the BIOS completely replaced. This took over two weeks. So much for being readily available. From what I have found out since then, this is a fairly common occurrence.
There are issues with working with the internet, where it randomly reloads pages without notice, which can be a problem if you are dealing with any type of online communications. I even spoke to HP about it, and their response was "Yeah, we know about that. It happens all the time. It is on our list of complaints to take care of." A list of common complaints? Really? And they are producing these without a fix anyway? Did they not test out the system before release?
Beyond that, for supposedly being a 2gig ram machine, it is incredibly slow. At start up it has at points taken over an hour to recognize a key stroke because the pre-loaded McAfee takes up 90% of processor capacity.
Each update I have run, some while trying to delay it to a more convenient time and it ran anyway, has instead of fixing issues made more. I have more than once had to recreate all the hot buttons and shortcuts to applications because an update wipes them out.
When I complained to HP about the speed issues and random wipes, again the said these were common complaints, and eventually updates should help clear up my complaints.
Over all, I got this machine because needed something reliable for school work. I am a graduating senior with multiple classes with online components. This machine failed me, and continues to do so, and has done nothing but make a stressful time much worse. It may be alluring because of the price, and coming in fun colors, but if you need it for anything beside just being bored and occasionally attempting to waste time, it will waste your time and money. Be prepared for frustrations and quite possibly loosing the system back to HP.

The fact that the Stream Laptops are sold in pink and blue versions suggests these cute lightweight laptops are being marketed to kids. But don't let the colors fool you.

This is a full-powered PC running Windows, but achieves a small size and light weight by eliminating the CD drive and replacing the hard drive with a 32GB digital drive. But it has 2 USB ports, an HDMI port, and a Micro-SD card slot, so there's plenty of ways to add more memory. You can always connect an external CD reader, or you can take the CD to another computer and copy the CD to a thumb drive.

For our purposes, we used the HDMI port to connect the Stream Laptop to a 60" video monitor. And we plugged the dongle for a wireless mouse into a USB port. And presto! One heck of an impressive computer for very little money.

This is a tough review, but here goes... I really wanted to like this computer. I teach at a local community college and I'm always on the lookout for inexpensive laptops to recommend to my students. A $199 (now $179, evidently) Windows 10 notebook with 1 year of Office 365 included seemed like a "too good to be true" offer. Well, it was, kinda. I'm not going to review the features, that's been done very well here and on Youtube by others, very accurately. Fit and finish for a computer of this price is impressive. However, the 32GB main storage (C:\ drive) is a deal-breaker. If you don't watch it closely, Windows will gobble up ALL this storage space for itself and you will find the thing unusable. I had to beat Windows down to a minimum and turn off all Windows updates to conserve this extremely limited (and un-expandable) storage space.  It DOES support an SD card as storage (shows up as D:\), but you must put a fair bit of effort  to install software to the D drive, not the default C drive. Again, it is do-able, but this is a serious nuisance and you need to pay close attention to direct every software install to the D drive. Even if you use cloud storage (a must), the local storage situation is terrible.

The other situation I encountered was that the "included" one year subscription of Office 360 was NOT included. I ended up spending over four hours on the phone over a three day period with HP Support trying to straighten this situation out. No gory details here, but it was as bad as you think it would be. I did, eventually, convince HP to send me a license for Office 365 but I wouldn't set my students (or my worst enemy) up for this experience.

Bottom line - a good computer for the money - sturdy, good battery life, kinda pokey but OK performance. But that 32 gb limit is a killer - Windows 10 eats disk space for breakfast and there just isn't enough space for Windows 10 and you at the same time. You lose, sorry.

I bought this at the spur of the moment because my previous laptop that was on its last leg bit the dust and I need a computer for a variety of reasons. I was a little nervous downsizing to a netbook computer, but I'm glad i made the choice. I am no longer a student and my laptop does not serve the same purpose as it used to. I also have a desktop, so most of my activities on my laptop were becoming Internet related.

I am absolutely pleased at the design. For the price, it is extremely sturdy and does not feel like it's going to break. It is super lightweight. I can transport it just about anywhere. I recently went on vacation and I was able to carry my laptop with me on the airplane. In addition, it is super sleek and small. It can fit in my purse and that helps in transporting it.

The processing speed can be slow at times. Like most netbooks, it is not good for multitasking. If I'm video chatting with someone on Skype, I pretty much can't use thew Internet because it tends to go super slow and lag the conversation. However, it is much better than previous netbooks I've encountered and it's not the biggest deal.

The biggest complaint I have is the storage. I'm happy that cloud storage is becoming a thing, but as technologies become more advanced ,the  files keep on getting bigger and I found that the memory of netbooks hasn't been able to keep up with that. This one is no exception. However, it is not the biggest deal, seeing I can upload my photos and documents to Dropbox and One Drive.

Overall, this is a great value and it exceeds my expectations for its price.

I received the computer, opened the box, and plugged it in and turned it on. The screen turned on, and the desktop appeared, but nothing else would happen -- no cursor, no ability to open programs, nothing. The on/off button would not work. Unplugging and plugging back in did nothing. The next day at work, I contact HP customer service, who were nothing but a waste of time. They offered no help, other than telling me to take the computer in for repairs. They didn't seem to understand that I had just paid for a NEW computer, not for a computer that had already broken and been repaired. I exchanged the computer through Amazon.

The new one arrived, and I opened the box, plugged it in, and turned it on. This time it worked, although it was already so slow that I was shocked. Trying to check my email took five times as long as it does on my old computer. And this was literally the first time I'd used the thing. In fact, the whole point of this computer seems to be that it's a trojan horse to get people to use a bunch of HP's favored apps -- they're built into the computer, taking up precious space, even though they're mostly useless and stupid. After I finally checked my email, I plugged my camera into the computer to download some pictures onto a popular photo-sharing website -- not downloading them onto the computer itself, mind you, but onto a website. What happened next? You guessed it, the computer crashed and would not work again no matter what I did. So all told, two brand-new computers worked for a grand total of 5 minutes before they both died.

I contacted HP customer service again, and got the same response -- send it in for repairs. I asked the HP person if this computer is just a scam. He didn't deny the notion, but he also didn't take my problems seriously or offer any real assistance, even when I told him that he was about to lose a customer forever. I returned it to Amazon and will never again buy anything for this shady company.

This laptop went from being something I nearly returned to a decent Windows 10 machine after I spent a fair amount of time sorting through device manager and updating all of the drivers.

I bought this computer for my elementary school aged daughter as her first laptop and we became quickly frustrated over how slowly it ran. CPU would spike to 100% upon boot up and generally stay there, occasionally drifting down to the 40-60% range before spiking to 100% again, with no applications actively running.

I bought the laptop with Windows 10 option installed and considered that maybe the hardware is too underpowered for the OS. After doing some investigation to troubleshoot the slow wireless connection, I saw advice on an HP support forum regarding the Windows 8.1 to 10 migration for this model to update the network adapter driver.

After that worked, I systematically checked all of the other drivers and about 25% of them, including graphics card, keyboard, etc, needed an update.

After the thorough driver updates, the laptop now runs much faster, CPU stays in the <20-30% range most of the time, and the applications behave as expected.

For a low cost laptop, the HP Stream runs acceptably if not exceptionally. Hopefully this advice about the drivers will help anyone encountering issues with running Windows 10 on this machine or give potential buyers something to consider when making a purchase (the driver updates are easy to do, they're just time consuming).

Microsoft is going to need to make a special Chromebook-type variant of Win10 if it wants to compete with Chromebooks. I don't think this is HP's fault - I bought this computer because I had a broken PC and I needed something fast and it did its job up to a point, but Win10 is just too heavy duty for this computer's hardware. Multitasking - as in, even multiple browser windows - is a recipe for slowness and aggravation.

It's a glorified tablet, except that it's not a touchscreen. The interface and jargon matches that of a tablet (or cell phone). So not very powerful, and certainly not possible to install any other OS on here.

On top of that, it's been a while since I've used a non-Linux operating system extensively, and my experience with this windows computer does not make me want to start again. I PAID for this computer; that means that I should be able to do WHATEVER I want with it; if I don't want to upgrade to Windows 10, I shouldn't have to be harassed by pop-ups over and over again. If I don't feel like I need anti-virus protection because I'm adequately safe in my use of the internet, I should be allowed to do that. But there was never an option to disable either of these ridiculously annoying pop-up notifications.

And here's the worst part: Finally, after 36 days of going unprotected, the computer told me I need to install anti-virus, without giving me the option to delay any longer. So I accepted Windows Defender, and then it asked me whether I want to give the program permission to install. So I said no. And the computer shut down, and cannot be turned back on anymore at all.

Windows sucks. It's really sad that we live in a world where paying LESS for my software gives me more freedom to do with it what I want to do with it.

This little thing is excellent for what I'm using it for.  It isn't very powerful, so if you're looking to play games, or do a whole lot with large programs this isn't the laptop for you.  I use it primarily for creating documents, light web surfing, maybe a little video streaming. It's perfect for that.  The battery lasts a long time, and it charges quickly.  It's extremely quiet as it's fanless, and it doesn't overheat.

My only small issue is that Windows 10 takes up most of the very small storage space, so you may want to place a microSD to add space.  I like Windows 10, but it is rather large.  It doesn't slow the machine though.  All in all I was really pleasantly surprised by this little laptop.  I had read other reviews which were good, and they were correct.  This is an affordable buy if you just want to have a good lightweight laptop to work on.
Battery life is great, performance leaves a little something to be desired, but it's really cheap so you can't quite ding it for that.

Practical, basic with lightweight, portable design.  Just because it does not have a fan does not mean it always runs cool.  Mine tended to run warm but no performance issues.  Stylish build, but some gaps between parts such as track pad and base.  Keys are very comfortable and well spaced.  The screen is good with clean picture.  Onboard memory is adequate, but plan on using an external hard drive for serious word processing/spreadsheets/powerpoint use.  Charges quickly, setup is logical, except included guidance/instruction is minimal.  Physical external design is great but it could use one more 3.0 or even 2.0 usb port.  Overall satisfied with thus device, great compliment to my external drive.

The mouse pad is very difficult to work with.  Stiff on the move... The product is overall okay.  It comes with a free up grade to Windows 10 but half way through the upgrade download the computer will stop to tell you that there is simply not enough space available unless you delete everything ...
I received my lap top with 9 out of 21 gigs available... But Windows ten needed 13.4 gigs of space to download.
Once I decided not to download the upgrade I managed to work with what I had and it seems so far that for the price paid this lap top mini is doing its job.... so far that is.
There are many web site errors.. something to do with the certificate.... whatever... I am not a computer kind of person so I have no idea how to fix it or get around it.  But the one reason I bought this computer was to access QuickBooks... And that website is not accessible on this lap top for some "website certificate authenticity error" reason....

Update;  I have full access to all websites now.  I did not change anything, but since the first day of use I have revised my opinion on this lap top from being just 3 stars to being 4 stars..  The mouse pad and the cursor is a bit difficult to work with, but I am sure I can get a new mouse and work it separate from the pad.
Oh and , as for the sound... for something as small as this lap top.. its got nice clear sound.

I tried 3 other laptops the same week I bought this one! The Acer Switch 10 lost sound and WiFi all the time and had no bluetooth. The ASUS Transformer T100HA froze or restarted every 5 minutes. The Acer Cloudbook 11 was okay but the touchpad was super broken. Oh, and none of those let me reverse the scrolling--a minor detail which drove me nuts.

The HP Stream has just worked out of the box. Thank goodness. I came from using a Chromebook for several years so I expected all of my laptops to just work, the way Chromebooks do. The HP is the only one that lived up to that expectation. It's nothing fancy, and it can be a little slow loading tabs in Chrome (even when sitting right next to the router), but for the price I can live with that. It actually gets phenomenal WiFi reception, to where I can use the home WiFi in my bedroom (which I've never been able to do with any laptop since I've lived here). I deleted some bloatware and added a 64 GB microSD card, and it's good to go. I needed to switch from the Chromebook in order to use iTunes for my new iPhone and Microsoft Office for work (I couldn't use the online version for the features I needed). So far, it's working perfectly. I'm relieved to finally have found a laptop that actually works.

I would give this computer negative stars if I could.  I had this computer for less than three months before the headphone jack became loose with regular use. I would only at times be able to hear the music in one ear.  This has never happened on any computer I've owned. I ended up sending the computer in for repair, thinking it would be no problem.  But they told me the heapdhone jack is soldered to the motherboard and that it had snapped off.  They said this was not a manufacturing defect and therefore was not covered under warranty, so it would cost $320 to replace the motherboard.  This is obviously way more than the cost of the computer.  I am now out $220 for a computer, plus $16 for shipping to the repair center,  all for a computer I was able to use at maximum working order for less than three months.  On top of it, the customer service rep was extremely curt and indifferent and essentially cut me off and hung up on me. I have had three HP's in my life but I will never buy from HP again.  This is clearly a company in decline. They are selling cut-rate products and don't care about the customer.  Don't be enticed by the price. In this case, you get less than what you pay for.

I was looking for a small and lightweight laptop, which my 10 y.o. niece could easily use for her computer needs. After reviewing a multitude of choices on Amazon, I decided to buy HP Stream 11.6-inch (Intel Celeron, 2 GB RAM, 32 GB SSD, Violet Purple) laptop. Since it was a Christmas gift for her, I did not have a chance to verify it was working. So, the first chance I got to open this laptop was after a New Year, since after Christmas, my niece took the gift home to play with it. Since she could not set it up herself, she brought it back to me. I took it out the box and checked if all the parts were present, properly packed and looked new. Then I opened the laptop and noticed a small piece of paper packing tape attached under the right side of the keyboard with some writing on (see the photo). It had serial number and some other number written by hand, which at that time should indicate a red flag for me. I proceeded with setting up the Microsoft Outlook account for a kid and adult (for supervision). Then, I activated the Microsoft Word subscription and installed the app. When I was done installing, everything seemed to work fine at first. The laptop was charging, the Microsoft Word seemed to function properly, and the only thing which I didn't like was the speed of the internet download, it was way too slow...I checked the internet connection and connected the laptop to my existing network. It was still slow, but I thought it is ok for 10 y.o. as a first laptop. So, I closed the laptop to make sure that the password I set up for my niece works. When I opened the laptop, the screen was dark and nothing was coming up. I tried several times closing and reopening it with the charger connected and without. I thought that  it was a glitchy charger, which I could easily replace. To test my theory, I used the charger from my own laptop, HP Notebook 15 (both laptops utilize 65W adapters). I waited for 15 min. to charge it for a bit, but it didn't work. I closed the laptop and left it closed for a day. The next day, I opened it again and to my surprise, it came alive...all the apps were working, Internet browsing was ok, so again, I thought that it was just a glitch, nothing serious. So, I brought this laptop back to my niece's house to let her get familiar with it and also to teach her how to properly use the Internet (how to utilize search criteria and proper syntax). The laptop was working well for a few hours, my niece was mainly using it for shopkins search. When she was done, she just closed it ( closed the lid). It stayed closed for a while, until I reopened it to search for something. When I reopened it, the screen was dark again and nothing was coming up. The power button was lit up, but the processor was quiet, as if there were no processes running on it. I was so frustrated with it, that I packed it back to its box and brought it home to ask my husband to look into it. He suggested to try a different charger again, and we made sure that when we inserted the charger, the white light on the right side of a laptop was on. So, we left it to charge for a whole day. The next day, when we reopened it again, no processes were running up, it was dead! We tried to reboot it with and without the charger (first, we used its own, then from my HP laptop) but it was still dead. The power button would light up when pressed on, but no processes were running and it remained dead quiet. It is still dead quiet now, as I am writing my review (wanted to make sure).
I am VERY dissatisfied with this product, as I am not sure if the seller sent me a refurbished laptop or just a bad one. Having found the piece of paper tape with the serial number and some other number written by hand, gives me real doubts regarding the quality and the state of the product. At this point I really wish I had purchased this laptop from reputable store and got a warranty on it. But most of all, I feel guilty and resentful that my gift to my niece, who was so thrilled to get it, was a total bust. Since it has been more than 30 days since the purchase, I can't return it or replace it. I spent $200 for nothing and really regret this purchase, since now I have to buy another laptop for my niece.
Lesson learned - will never buy any electronics from Amazon again!

This is a well built laptop with a nice keyboard, and it comes with a full version of Windows on it. Overall, I recommend it for people who need basic computing, shopping, working online, social networks, etc. Given its price, I was almost ready to give it 5 stars, because it really is incredible that this machine can do what it does for just over $200. However, I think it's necessary to point out its shortcomings so that people know what they are getting and can compare this to a mid price machine.

First, the screen is really quite poor. It seems a bit faded and dim, and if you're not looking at it straight on, it's very hard to see it (i.e. It has a narrow view range).

Second, the touchpad mouse is not very sensitive. This is more annoying because it is something that one uses constantly, so it's a constant reminder of the comprise you're making with this machine. It works, but just takes getting used to. Disclosure- I usually use Macs, which have some of the best trackpads out there, so perhaps my expectations are unreasonable- but again, I wanted to make sure to be honest here.

Finally, it is quite slow, especially before you take off some of the crapeware that comes pre-installed. Other reviews have very good directions for which programs to remove. Remove them, it will run better.

I was going to list the tiny 32 GB solid state hard drive as a negative, but really, that is pretty minor these days. If you need more storage, SD cards are easy to get and affordable, and if you have more storage needs for photos or videos, this is not the machine for you (or, of course, simply use an external hard drive).

Let me start off on a positive note  It's a very pretty laptop.  And if you're looking for a prop for a play or video or something and you have two hundred dollars to spend on that kind of thing, then by all means.  This would make a wonderful prop.

Or if perhaps you need a paperweight.

Other than that, DO NOT BUY THIS LAPTOP. NOT WITH WINDOWS 10.  It says 32 GB hard drive.  And I TOTALLY understand the concept of a cloud device.  But, when you can't even install Office 365 (which is approximately 3GB, mind you), after Windows 10 installs and all the updates occur, then, what exactly is the point of this?  (I installed NOTHING, all I did was turn on the thing and sign into my Microsoft account) It's WORSE than a tablet, because the OS uses up almost 100% of the CPU, so the internet is ALWAYS slow, no matter the connection.

It comes with a year of Office 365. Which you can't install because the OS takes up all the HD space.  So, yay?  Thanks for teasing with the prospect of a working device that you could actually USE Office 365 on.

And don't be fooled by that 14 GB of free space after you set everything up.  It will disappear as updates are installed.  You can watch it happen, if you're a masochist or something.  It will dwindle and dwindle as if by magic, until only 2.85 GB are remaining. Disc cleanup doesn't work at all, because there is JUST Windows 10 on this device.  Nothing to fall back on.

I do however, have some alternate name ideas for HP:  Hp Stream Craptop.  Maybe the HP Stream Nopebook?  Either of those.  Because this isn't a laptop.  It's just LIES.

For this computer to work well, you need to remove all the junk that comes pre-installed, including their anti-virus ware--then install a low-footprint anti-virus of your own (free ones work great, but remember they're free so they'll have upgrade ads every time you start up, and those slow your computer down slightly). Make sure only your browser of choice is installed. Make sure you check all the start-up programs for anything that you don't absolutely need. There are YouTube videos that take you step by step through this whole process. At the end you'll have a laptop that starts up nearly as fast as a phone or ipad. Then carefully install ONLY the software you need! Make sure you're using the OneDrive for all your saving--dont' be putting stuff on the desktop or saving in weird locations without immediately deleting once you're finished with whatever it is.

Personally I would use a wireless mouse (amazon has a great one for super cheap) and not the touchpad...but it's nice to have the touchpad if you either forget the mouse or don't want to tote something extra. I would also recommend picking up a memory card if you want to install extra software--you want to try and minimize your footprint in the 32gigs of onboard storage where you can. But files (as opposed to applications) should generally be saved to your OneDrive

Now you have a fast, lean, tiny laptop. From here you'll want to build your usage around online apps (like a chromebook) where possible. But the HUGE advantage over a chromebook is that you've got a fully functional Window 10 computer to run those Windows programs that you really want/need. Plus you get a year of Office 365 and a TB of storage on OneDrive for free.

Who am I? I'm a professional visual effects artist. I work in 3ds Max and Maya 3D files that have billions of polygons and Photoshop documents that are hundreds of gigs in size. Do I use this for work? No, of course not--no laptop can replace a workstation for my work. Do I use it for writing in Word and spreadsheeting in Excel? ABSOLUTELY. Do I use it for its near instant-on start up and surfing the web. ABSOLUTELY. Playing movies and music? ABSOLUTELY. What is it like? Well, it's like a Chromebook but with more flexibility.

My wife has one that she uses for her work--her work requires her to use the Firefox browser to run proprietary software that runs through Firefox. If you have a Chromebook, you can ONLY use the chrome browser--you can't use IE and you can't use Firefox. That's a limitation that sometimes crops up where you least expect it. For instance, I've had studios (Disney (ILM) for instance) where the benefits portal does not support Chrome. If I had a Chromebook, I'd be locked out from those portals. Because of the nature of our use, we cannot limit our computer usability just to support google and chrome.

Arrived on schedule, in perfect condition. It was for a gift - everyone loved the color! Very nice compact size. I was pleased that the keyboard was actually large enough to "type" not just hunt and peck. Seller was great!

In short, I love my HP Stream far more than I expected to. I bought the Violet Purple laptop with a 13.3 screen. The color is gorgeous and eye-catching, I love the gradient purple. More than one person has enviously commented on the color, and the 13.3 screen is perfect for me. I'm a writer, so I spend a lot of time staring intently at the screen. The 11 inch screens are usually too small for me, but 13.3" is just right. The laptop is also surprisingly sturdy for something so lightweight and inexpensive. The last laptop I bought was an Asus (which cost 100 more dollars than my HP Steam) and the Asus seemed much less durable and more prone to pick up smudges. The fact that the HP Stream is smudge-resistant is important to me too.

I had a Chromebook once, but found I couldn't use it (again, because I'm a writer) I couldn't handle being restricted to google docs, so I appreciated that the HP Stream was an affordable Windows laptop. Programs like OpenOffice and Office are a must for me. Because I use it mainly for word processing (and to surf for the occasional youtube video or check twitter) it suits my needs just fine. It's a little slower than some computers I've worked on, but since it's much less expensive than those computers, it feels like a steal. It certainly wouldn't be a good computer for gaming or anything like that, but it's perfect for me.

If I had one small complaint, it would be the keyboard. It seems a little cheap, and when I really get going, it sounds like it's squeaking a little bit. This is just a small thing though. The small 32 GB of storage can also fill up very quickly, but that would be easily solved by saving your stuff to a USB.

All in all, I was extremely satisfied with this little computer. I even considered buying another one in a different color.

I'm a Linux and Chromebook user...stopped using Windows OS several years ago.  Purchased this machine for a class I'm teaching that requires MS Excel. Pros:
--  Light as a feather.
--  Excellent battery life.  I'm getting on average about 9-10 hours.
--  Keyboard OK.  Good key response, full keyboard.
--  11.6 inch screen display is OK.  Some people don't like the size (think it's too small).  I'm comfortable with it...have used a 11.6 inch Chromebook for some years due to lots of travel and wanting something small and light.
--  Didn't have to pay for Office 365 (for a year, at least).
--  Increased my OneDrive storage from 111GB to 1.1TB.
--  Connects to WiFi OK.

Cons:
--  Sloooow.  Underpowered with only 2GB memory (cannot upgrade) and the Celeron N3050.  Even after killing a bunch of services, reducing the programs at startup, and removing most of the garbage-ware that comes on it, web pages render slowly, streaming videos stutter, even with nothing else running.
--  Very small storage.  Windows 10 takes up quite a bit of the 32GB SSD (cannot upgrade)...left with something like 10GB for file storage.  It's supposed to be focused on storing things on OneDrive...there may still be times you want to store files locally.
--  Because of the small SSD, couldn't even do a Windows update until adding a micro SD card (I used a 32GB) because of the size of the update file.

Great little laptop for all kinds of tasks. I've owned this laptop since January, 2015 and there has been little wear on the body, save for the touchpad. I've used Visual Studios, Photoshop and Java development on this laptop. Had to get a 16 GB SD card, but this laptop could use a lot more space. I'd say no less than 200 GB. Here are my thoughts on this laptop:

Pros:
- Speedy processor; excellent Windows 10 companion laptop for a desktop
- Upgrade-able SSD (IF you can find the WWAN module board)
- Light enough to carry with one hand
- Very durable plastic
- Runs cold even with full utilization

Cons:
- Screen quality is grainy and pixelated and is far too dark or bright
- Ugly blue (will repaint this a different color)
- Poor speaker quality
- Touchpad is sometimes unpredictable. I recommend buying a mouse or swapping this one out from a compatible HP Chromebook
- Side light is not necessary, would opt for a hard drive activity light instead
- Non upgradeable RAM and processor
- No DVD ROM drive

Overall, I recommend getting a Chromebook unless you really must use Microsoft Windows. This blue color is a turn-off at a developer's conference or business meeting because it makes this look cheap. The screen looks bad at many angles because of it's matte design. HP can do better for a $200 laptop!

I have no idea how they can sell this product with a straight face. I got the model with windows 10. I'm generally a fan of HP products and bought my mother a full sized HP laptop that is working out great. Unfortunately, this one is just too damn slow. Both my kids needed laptops for schoolwork. I wasn't sure if I wanted to go with a chromebook or stick to windows just for the sake of compatibility. The chromebook setup in minutes. This HP model took what felt like forever. Every step required several minutes of waiting. After it was done, it was slow as molasses. I figured it might still be configuring stuff in the background, so I just let it run for a bit. Just trying to bring up a simple web page in microsoft edge would peg the processor at 100%. I tried installing chrome, but that also took up full processor usage just to view cnn. I tried uninstalling every piece of non-essential software which helped a little, but the computer was still basically unsuable for browsing the internet. Meanwhile, the chromebook (ASUS Chromebook 13 Inch HD with Gigabit WiFi, 16GB Storage & 4GB RAM (Light Blue)), seemed blazing fast. I really have no idea how anyone is actually using this HP computer. I was even tempted to install some flavor of linux to see if I could get some decent performance out of it, but I really didn't feel like I should have to do something so drastic just to get a single webpage to load in a timely fashion. Since the processor was maxed out, it felt like I was on dialup again. Looking at some of the other reviews on here, I'm not alone in experience this issue.

Got this on a fluke as I needed a cheap throwaway laptop to travel with, and if it weren't for the 32gig built in memory, which realistically turns to about 20gig once you have Office and Windows 10 in there. Luckily, it takes an extra MicroSD card for storage and these are pretty inexpensive.
Overall I am impressed by the speed of this little machine, battery life is great, the 13in screen is adequate and it definitely beats a tablet. Windows 10 came loaded with a lot of unnecessary crap being part of the Microsoft store and a few other unnecessary programs, luckily I was able to uninstall these with ccleaner, including the ones that won't uninstall from the Windows 10 menu.

I installed Office 2010 on mine (not the Office365) and runs without a hitch.

Skype works well, as does Netflix. It has Bluetooth so you can stream audio to your portable speakers, share data with your phones, etc.

The speakers are loud enough for what it is, even though they might be a bit bass light even for laptop, but they're better than what I expected.
Also, lets not forget to mention the lightness of this unit - due to the fact that it is basically a glorified tablet with keyboard you save on weight and get extended battery life, and almost the performance of a fully fledged laptop, at least for normal everyday use.

I am very impressed and honestly, I regret owning a tablet as this seems to be much better suited to my needs and will probably get a lot more use.

Before I rant, let me tell you what it does do well: my 7 year old daughter uses it to practice her typing online (web-based program), and to practice her simple math, also using a web based program. She stays logged in, pops it open, waits a few minutes for it to figure out where it is and then whammo, she's off and running.

Now the rant.
1. Changing signed in users generally results in the black screen of death. If you're patient the computer may find its way to an actual desktop but I  am generally done by about fifteen minutes and do a hard reboot.

2. Syncing files for Google Drive is RIDICULOUSLY SLOW. One edit to one file (file size 3mg) took... I timed it.... 17 minutes. My favorite laptop, same wireless network, took less than 2. This has resulted in more than one file being corrupted when the computer gives up, goes to sleep, or I don't realize that it's not finished. When you're writing a novel a corrupted file is kind of an emergency.

I expected to make some compromises at this price point, but I'm not exaggerating when I say that my phone has more processing power than this product. Unless you're buying it for your (little) kid, don't buy this thing. So disappointed.

Over the years my wife and I have bought thousands of dollars in HP electronics.  We bought the HP Stream for my son as his first laptop.  He had the laptop for seven months and the earphone jack stopped working.  We shipped the computer back to HP and they said they'd fix the earphone jack for $350.  Of course, this seemed crazy to me considering the computer didn't cost $350 to begin with.  After trying to logically talk through why this did not make sense with HP customer support (actually seven different people) I had them ship the computer back to me.  When the computer was returned it had a big scratch on the exterior of the computer and it wouldn't even turn on.  We called HP back customer support again and they said, effectively, it was our problem.  I've decided that HP stands for "horrible products" and will not ever buy another HP product.  If you buy this computer just know it will not last long.  So if you want to spend $200 on a computer that may last a year then go for it.  One final note, we called Amazon and explained what happened.  Amazon graciously took back the computer and gave us a full credit.  That, my friends is customer service and that is why I will be an Amazon customer for life!

I actually bought this from Walmart, not Amazon, but absolutely love this product nonetheless and decided to write a few tips here (including how to use it with a pen!)

I honestly think the Stream does something unique. Does anyone here remember the iBook Clamshell from Apple and how unique and wonderful it was to hold one? Today, in an overflowing myriad of thin aluminum, this has disappeared. HP manages to bring up those memories with this model, offering it in two vibrant, striking colors and an all plastic design that's for everyone. It's light design and minimal ports remind me of a more reasonable price for the recent MacBook as well.

You don't get backlit keys or a re-invented keyboard. You don't get a premium display. You don't get one lone USB C port. You don't get that great of a camera, and you only get a simple diver-board style ClickPad.

But what you do get is an economy netbook that behaves like a bona-fide computer. The first thing to do (and all bias aside, I am *completely* serious about this!) is to get rid of Windows 8.1! You can strip out the apps, etc. you don't use, but both it and the recovery partition take up quite a bit of room on the tiny 32GB eMMC flash drive, leaving you crunched on here. But, I would *really* recommend to make a Recovery USB first, though, in case you need to reflash it, resell it, or are new to it all and change your mind. Spending a while configuring Gnu/Linux right to where I wanted it was well worth it. I had 75% of my disk free for use, and I really felt processor performance went up. Minus the additional 2 seconds for legacy mode, OS boot time was also pretty fast (10-15 seconds), but all this is also because of careful fine-tuning... and that it went right to a bare X.org with light programs.

As for hardware, this has a weak (but good) webcam for the price, a dual mic to match it, a fairly decent keyboard (do NOT pound the poor thing or it will break!) and Wifi and Bluetooth built right in. One USB 2 and one USB 3 port, along with HDMI, and 3.5 mm audio in are included, as well as a SD card slot on the right. The feel is very solid (in fact impressive, considering this computer's class), and the hinges are very responsive. The ClickPad works great, and I've had no problems with it when my fingers are clean and dry. Fine-tuning Touchpad settings is a definite need, however, so that it works the way you like.

This machine has a really awesome processor, related to the M family. In essence, though, it is simply a fan-less (seriously; I disassembled the notebook) Intel Celeron N2840 clocking at 2.16 GHz. Gratefully, Vt-x is supported for running virtual machines for anyone like me who needs to use that (even if it is just on the go), and both UEFI and legacy boot modes are supported.

This isn't for games, and was built simply for mediocre, everyday video streaming (hence Stream), writing documents, and Web browsing to compete with the Chromebooks. For me, I simply wanted something to replace my aging tablet PC to draw icons on and write software with on the go. So, why am I so excited? What makes this computer so cool, really?

- USB 3! Seriously -- this cheap, entry-level machine has this built right in... and I was expecting just two USB 2 ports standard. Copies are inherently faster, and disk access from external drives is fairly snappy, even with the lagging eMMC storage this has in it, and I was generally (and genuinely) impressed.

- Expansion. The SD card slot was a very, very wise decision, as 32 GB of extra space literally make the little storage this machine comes with humanly livable with a quick mount script and symlinks (or if you have Windows 7+, just set up Libraries to point your folders over). I might also mention that you could also dedicate extra swap space with a portable image to get more out of the 2 GB of RAM in here as well.

- Efficiency. Out of curiosity, I compiled a full snapshot for a software project I work on (as of this writing) utilizing both cores, and put the computer on its side rather than in a normal bottom-down position to better dissipate heat. Despite not having a fan, it surprisingly did not overheat (Linux reported sensor temps at 75 C, which was warm, but definitely not 90 C hot) and went through the compilation just 50% slower than my mobile workstation with a much faster processor. Again, same as with the USB 3, I was impressed at this performance for this level of machine -- especially with a humble Celeron, which are famously slow.

- Battery. This is seriously like carrying an iPad around with a lid (and yes, you can use it like a tablet. See the next point for that...) as it gets an incredible 6 hours of use! And I really like the thin tipped new generation adapter HP is including with the Stream, etc. as well. The battery is not user servicable, but it is not soldered (I took the bottom plate off), so like the Envy, on the day the battery finally goes out, it shouldn't be too much of a challenge if you're experienced to simply pop in a new one.

- Matte screen (which also means "Hello, pen!"). To start with, there are no annoying reflections of the world on here! While the color depth is not the greatest and you get a standard 1280x800 resolution, it is uniform with a good LED backlight, and that also means something else -- something really important. If you buy a (good) optical pen from eBay or on here, etc. you can pair the pen to a dongle and tune the settings to your liking. From there, while you will not have a point-to-point interaction with it (the pointer will move independently of the pen's placement), you can draw, click, and move the pointer around the screen, saving you $100s from buying a convertible or other hardware if it works for you. I personally found doing this really cool. :-)

Overall, I am seriously in love with this machine -- and I have not felt this for a really long time. I literally have been finding myself spending more time with it over my workstation, thanks to its awesome portability and the pen hack! Buy this little computer -- with the right expectations, you won't be sorry you did!

I really, really wanted to like this computer, but I'm having a hard time doing so. It came with Windows 10 - right out of the box, it installed 11 updates, after which I got the message that it failed to "upgrade to Windows 10 Home, version 1511, 10586" because it needed more space! I googled the error, and found the suggestion that the recovery partition be copied to a flash drive and then deleted from the hard drive, in order to free up the necessary space. Except that this can't be done on newer HP Streams like mine, because they have no separate, free-standing recovery partition any more. Also, though the computer comes with Windows Defender, there was no way for me to turn it on. I had uninstalled McAfee right off the bat, so there should be no conflict with another anti-virus program, but the option to turn on Defender remains grayed out, Also, I find the computer to be surprisingly slow for a brand new machine, and the microphone is defective (so I can't use Skype).
I'm only planning to use this computer for email and general browsing, so I don't expect to need a lot of storage space - but I sure didn't expect the computer to not even have enough space for Windows updates! I will try a clean installation of Win 10 from a USB drive - I've read people have had some success with that - but I wouldn't recommend that for someone who's not comfortable "messing around" with a new computer.

Purchased this basically for writing and research as I enjoy working with Microsoft Word and this came with the one year free subscription. Unfortunately, I didn't do enough homework here, or rather, some drawbacks of this operating system were not clearly stated. First off, my laptop did not come with a passcode to access Microsoft Office Personal. After multiple chat sessions and an hour waiting to chat with an HP rep, I was told that a manager would have to contact me in the next 24-48 hours. They did and offered to send me Microsoft Office Home via mail. Then they called back and left a message stating they couldn't "confirm" that this offer had come with my purchase and I had to send them photos of my invoice and the stickers on the laptop and box. Ridiculous, but I did it anyway. A day later my passcode and disc (completely useless given that this device has no CD ROM drive) arrived, however, I was still unable to access office and needed to spend another hour and a half via phone with Microsoft to remove the installed software, reinstall it, and get everything running. Great? No. Though the Microsoft service was far preferable to HP, I've now discovered that I'm unable to attach files in Chrome, the e-mail and other services I prefer to use for my basic internet use. This is due to the fact that photos and info are stored via flash which isn't compatible, yadda, yadda, yadda, after several internet searches, I've discovered this and it sucks. Uploading photos, even with a separate card reader, was a nightmare with no ease of use and difficulty transferring them to other locations. I'm unable to return the product since it is apparently functioning just fine, but it is not at all what I'd expected and the memory is even worse than advertised. Crapware everywhere. I'm beyond disappointed and will, unfortunately be stuck with this device. Do yourselves a favor and spend an extra $100 to get something more multi-functional.

I bought this machine to replace an aging laptop my son uses at college.  Full disclosure:  I bought the machine at a local retailer instead of Amazon.  I wanted a quick way to return it if it wouldn't work.  My son is an Engineering student and prefers Linux to Windows, so compatibility with Ubuntu / Xubuntu was a key factor in the choice.  There is one MAJOR linux "gotcha" with this machine: wifi - more info further into the review.

As delivered using Windows 10, the machine seems OK at best.  32GB of storage and 2GB of memory are not really enough to make the Stream 11 useful for anything more than casual browsing and video streaming.  You won't want to play games or do anything compute intensive.  The included AV software is a particular drag on performance.  While I was trying to create the recovery drive, AV would suck up to 45% of available CPU.  I uninstalled it and finally created the recovery USB stick.  Next, I used HP's utility to update the BIOS and several other programs.  Once the machine BIOS was updated, I proceeded to install Xubuntu 15.10.

The machine booted from the install USB and everything worked, albeit with a very low wifi signal.  I selected "something else" during the setup and wiped only the Win10 partition.  I wanted to leave the recovery and diagnostics partitions so I could return the machine to its original state if it just didn't work out.  In the free partition, I created a 2G Swap partition and used the rest for Xubuntu.  I did not download updates during the installation, preferring to do this once the machine is running.

Once up, it booted immediately to the Xubuntu desktop but wifi was spotty.  I used a USB Ethernet dongle and hardwired connection to my network, then installed updates. After the update and restart, wifi stopped working completely!  Making a long story short, there is a driver related problem with the Realtek RTL8723be wifi in this machine.  The fix has two parts:
- install an updated driver as documented here:  http://askubuntu.com/questions/590414/wifi-problems-with-rtl8723be-in-ubuntu-14-04  Note this will not cure the problem just get wifi working if you are sitting right next to an access point
- Open the machine and move the single antenna to the other connector on the router.  Yes, you have to physically OPEN THE MACHINE.  HP, for whatever reasons, elected to only put one antenna wire in the case even though the wifi adapter supports two.  The Linux driver cannot currently detect the port with the best signal and simply uses one antenna - the wrong one.  It's not difficult to lift the keyboard and make the change, once you realize there are screws under the feet and two small rubber plugs.  A credit card allows lifting the keyboard without marring the plastic case.  The wifi adapter is at the back-right; the black wire has a teeny-tiny connector that snaps onto the adapter and can be easily moved to the other port.  Still, it's not a pretty fix.  If you are willing to make this change, you'll be rewarded with great wifi performance.  The linux driver maintainer is currently working with Realtek to find a software solution to the problem.  The other alternative, of course, would simply be to use a supported USB wifi adapter, but where's the challenge in that?

The last change I made was to edit /etc/fstab, move temp directories to a ramdisk and add "noatime" to the main partition, to save write wear and tear on the eMMC/SSD.

Everything else "just works".  Booting is quicker than Win10 by a good margin.  Screen resolution is excellent. Touchpad works as expected.  Bluetooth support is great.  I paired an HP6000 bluetooth mouse; it works great and I was stunned to see that clicking the "battery level" icon showed the mouse battery level as well as the system!

Were it not for the wifi issue, this would be a five-star machine.  At the price of a Chromebook, you get a truly great day-to-day Ubuntu machine with full program support.

This was a Christmas present this year for my daughter, primarily for web browsing, some apps and doing homework. After ONLY ONE WEEK, it stopped charging and when we shut it down (properly) the screen went black (as if it were off), yet the power light remained on - meaning, you can't power it on/off. We tried holding down the power button and nothing happens. We called HP support and they were hopeless (e.g. the rep asked me to take the battery out when the HP Stream doesn't even have a removable battery!). Our only hope now is to return it and get our money back. To state that we are extremely disappointed is a huge understatement.

**UPDATE: We let the power completely run out and then charged the laptop. When we turned it back on, we realized it had just gone through an automatic update. After doing a lot of research, we learned that these little laptops can't handle ANY updates. My husband updated all the settings and removed the HP software that caused the problem (not sure exactly what he did though). Since then the computer has been working with no issues. I have upgraded my rating because we were able to keep and use the laptop as intended. However, there is a serious flaw when a PC can't handle its own updates so I can't give it more than 3 stars.**

I got this laptop for Christmas and I love it! The color is a beautiful dark purple on the outside with the same dark purple to a lighter purple gradient on the inside. The color definitely isn't childish, which is what I've been seeing a lot. I'm a freshmen in high school and it does exactly what I want/need it to do. First of all, the battery life is amazing. I've had it last up to 7 hours on one charge. It can also do quite a bit at once. I don't know what people are complaining about. I watched Netflix while downloading a game and had no problems. Also, unlike what lots of people have said, it CAN play games. I've been able to run Sims 4 on low settings, the first Mass Effect, Skyrim (but it was a bit laggy), and a few other simple games. I've put all of these on an external hard drive. If you want to play games, just don't expect to play new big games on it. It can run things that are a bit older or aren't as demanding games, but don't expect to run Fallout 4 or something like that. Back to other things, It comes with a free year of windows 365, which is very useful because I'm in high school. It also comes with a month of McAfee protection stuff. The only bad thing I could say about this laptop is that sometimes the sound is a bit weird. It's happenend a few times where the sound was almost.. demonic? That's a good word to describe it. The sound slows down a lot or lags or something, but it's fixable by restarting the computer.

I purchased this based on some of the positive Amazon reviews, as a replacement for my Chromebook.  I expected a slight performance hit--after all, Windows 10 is heavier than ChromeOS--but the computer itself is almost unusable.  Using Microsoft Edge, any more than four tabs grinds the machine to a halt.  Even YouTube videos stutter in a small screen.  Don't even think about installing Chrome--this doesn't have the gas to run that browser.  Worse yet, if Window 10 decides it going to download some updates or perform "maintenance" while you're working, the entire machine grinds almost to a halt.

Things get a bit better if you uninstall every bit of bloatware that HP "helpfully" installs for you.  Not much, however.  Basically, if you need to run Windows, spend an extra $100 or so and buy a more powerful computer. If you're looking to browse the web, buy a Chromebook. This box of half measures doesn't do much of anything well.

Please, folks, do your homework before giving this laptop one star because it doesn't have an optical drive, doesn't have a ton of storage, etc. etc. This laptop is bare bones. I think it was actually engineered fairly well for what it is --- which is, a bare bones system designed for basic tasks like email, internet browsing, and using office applications (spreadsheets, word processing, etc.). It's not going to run games well (though it will run Minecraft fine on the lowest graphic settings), it probably won't play HD movies very smoothly, and with only two gigs of RAM you aren't going to be running many applications at once.

Tips if you get it - install the free version of Revo Uninstaller, and uninstall all of the bloatware that comes on any big-brand laptop. If the 32 gigs of storage space isn't enough, buy a SD card to keep in the laptop to store your media on, or buy an external SSD drive. Just remember to backup your data.

Side note - can't stand all the one star reviews on here from people who don't know jack about computers and are whining because it "Doesn't have a CD-ROM drive" or "Won't play the Sims". Simple fact that even tech-challenged people can understand -- all computers are NOT created equally. But this is a good thing. It's like cars. You can buy a Ferrari, but you probably don't need one and can't afford one, even though they're superb. But that's okay. A Civic is still a decent car that will get you to point B. Just don't expect it to do zero to sixty in a few seconds. Same thing here. This laptop is sort of like the Civic. And I think it's a great little machine.

Looking for a notebook that can keep up with your busy day? Then the HP Stream is NOT your best choice. In fact, this may be the first time I'm looking forward to the speed of UPS and USPS when it returns this laptop.
More than likely, you'll want it because of its looks, which I totally understand. I waited years for companies to start bringing color to the laptops, knowing full well that it would be more of a distraction to the purchaser who'd eventually notice the downgrading of the laptop. And make no mistake - HP is famous for their "Pay no attention to what my right hand is doing" while waving their left hand in front your face.

I come from a family of HP engineers, back when Hewlett and Packard lived long enough to oversee their products built with the integrity they lost long before Carly Fiorina came on the scene. That's right - by the 1998, HP was well on the road to becoming what you see today - a company who's products appear all bright and shiny on the outside, but packed with tons of product placements that offers 30 days free for things you either already have or don't need, leaving you with spending more time removing, uninstalling, cleaning and reinstalling -sometimes three times! - just to completely clear out all the files that hide in the little nooks and crannies of the machine.
And that's just the beginning:

If you are using this to keep you occupied while sitting in the doctor's office, just know that the RAM and Storage on this thing is pretty much spent the moment you turn it on with its Windows8 and/or Windows10 software. Think about it: On your regular 15in laptop, how much space does Windows take up? Now add Microsoft Office (I'm a 2010 Office person, so you won't ever see me trying to work with 365 -ever), Mcaffee (because you already know what a hog Norton is) and just for the heck of it, load something you know requires a minimum amount of  space and speed (That's not even possible anymore).  Okay? Great.
Now go about your day. By the time you begin moving about the internet, collecting cookies, filling out your name, email address so Microsoft and the others can have even more access to your business, you'll find yourself cursing the machine, as you finger punch your keyboard trying to coax it to comply with what the advertisers promised in the beginning. And for gods sake, don't try and read your email!!!

Trust me, by this time, you are no longer focusing on the pretty colors. You're too busy beating your head on the table for buying a 232.00 mini laptop, that runs 10 times slower than your kid's Dell 15in laptop, with 4GB RAM, 230GB storage, which only costs 70.00 more (At Micro-Center). I don't know if Fisher-Price is making computers for the "little ones," but I wouldn't be surprised to hear stories of parents, tucking their kids into bed earlier, just to use their computer, which would no doubt be faster.

Oh yeah, and here's the kicker:
No CD/ROM and no way to open it up to modify. I take that back. You could open it up, but what a waste of time for the amount of money you pay. If it had a CD/ROM, you could justify buying it to watch movies, but do we already have that in another system? Then what is HP trying to accomplish here? Heaven forbid, HP should stop thinking their bottom line, and focus on products that would bring back faithful Return Customers, right?
But that's HP for you - Always looking to the "turnover" customers, because that's where their real profits lie - in the buying habits of those who have yet to discover the true uselessness of HP in the 21st century. Oh, by the way, have you noticed that many HP mouse have been USB- modified to fit only THEIR computers? A little more than  simply selfish, don't you think? Standardization is no longer key to their bottom line.

Look, I've loved HP for years, and you can still pretty much get a pretty good HP laptop today (I bought an HP 17in last year, but I had to return two before that in order to get one worth the price), but you have to do your homework, and resign yourself to a period of modification, as with all laptops today. It's just unfortunate that HP who could have maintained it's position as a forerunner to providing quality products for the consumer,  chose to go the route of shortcuts and trying to sell expensive warranties that they hate having to honor.

Finally, and this is not a political statement for or against Carly Fiorina, but I'll say it again: Don't fall for the hype that she was responsible for the way HP turned out. HP was going downhill fast and Carly got paid good money to wear that truth around her neck.

You get what you pay for.  For word processing and internet searches it is fast enough, but add in skype, or any other program, and then the system gets bogged down quickly.  It's perfect as a second computer or for travel, but I would upgrade to something with a few more frills if you plan on doing more than light duty work.

A few glaring cons, though: 1) The trackpad is horrible.  The solid click and double tap don't work as well as some reviews claim, response is slow, but it can also be oddly sensitive.  When typing if my hand brushes it it will respond when I don't need it to, but when I'm actively trying to use it the darn thing doesn't work so well. 2) The screen is also terrible.  Whites appear too bright even when you mess with the color schemes and it can be distracting, plus it has tight viewing angles. 3) The keyboard takes some getting used to.  It's justified to the left so my fingers will hit wrong keys all the time.

That being said, having Win 10 vs. a Chromebook makes this computer more flexible. The hard drive is quick and adding a Micro SD card isn't so bad.  I would take this over a chromebook any day.
