Really happy with this laptop;  typing on it now in fact.  Fantastic value for such a low price.  First of all I live in reality.  I have to laugh when I read some of these reviews;  I mean come on, this is a sub $200 laptop, not a Cray or Watson computer.  Didn't you even read the specs?  I have a powerful 4 core desktop as my main computer and just wanted something super portable while on the road so I will not have to strain while trying to read my smartphone screen, or struggle with the tiny on-screen keyboard keys.  I also wanted all the Windows programs I like with me that I normally use.

PROS:

1) Sharp easy to read bright screen.

2) Much faster than I expected given the low specs.  It is really just the load time of very large programs that I give it a ding for.

3) Very portable and lightweight.  Would have gone with the 13 if that was not my criteria.

4) It is so cheap that if it breaks or somebody steals it I will not go ballistic.

5) EDIT ON 01-24-2018.  Replaced Windows with Linux mint 18.3 because there was not enough space on the laptop to perform any more Windows updates.

6) This will be perfect for communicating with my Raspberry Pi fireworks launcher via wifi in the field:

[...]

CONS:

1)  Yes it only has a small amount of drive space. That said, I knew that before I ordered it and added a 32GB SDHC card to my order.  I installed a ton of programs on the SD Card which still leaves me with 8 GB on the main drive.

2) EDIT: SOLVED ON 01-28-2016. Wireless reception is really poor under Linux.  FIX IS LOCATED HERE:

[...]

EDIT AGAIN ON 01-24-2018.  Linux Mint 18.3 with the latest kernel includes the Realtek driver option to select the antenna port to fix the poor wifi signal (CAUTION: This is for the 11-r010nr model with the Realtek rtl8723be wireless chipset only.  I see other HP Streams may or may not have the same wifi hardware so you would need to investigate)  The external Realtek drivers from lwfinger are no longer necessary.  So, to fix the wireless run:

a) sudo modprobe -r rtl8723be
b) sudo modprobe -v rtl8723be ant_sel=2

c) Create a new file.

  vi /etc/modprobe.d/50-rtl8723be.conf

 Add the following to the file

  options rtl8723be ant_sel=2 ips=0

d) reboot.  The wifi signal should double or more.

3) I wish it had just one more USB port.  I often have to find workarounds because I need to connect another device to that missing third port.

4)  EDIT: SOLVED THIS PROBLEM ON 12-27-2015 (SEE BELOW): Only a couple of Linux versions will load from a bootable usb memory stick.  I especially wanted to run Clonezilla so I could make image backups, but it just will not start up.

The following versions of Live Linux distributions do load fine though:
Lubuntu 15.10
Mint 17.3

Still working on that problem.

PROBLEM SOLVED:

So, this was really bothering me, so I played around with it this morning a bit. It was recommended by the Clonezilla author that I try Tuxboot and/or another USB drive brand. So first I tried Tuxboot with Clonezilla 2.4.2-61 Stable and initially it didn't work like all my other attempts. However this time I noticed a new boot option in the boot menu:

Whereas the only boot option before was:

USB Hard Drive - Sandisk Extreme......

A new entry appeared when using Tuxboot, and with Clonezilla being the only ISO on the USB drive:

USB Hard Drive (EUFI) - Sandisk Extreme

So, I gave it a try and a slightly different Clonezilla main menu popped up. It was a plain text menu of the normal selection of choices (resolution, etc) rather than the normal scrollable menu. Also, on top of the screen was the following text...."GNU grub version 2.02 Beta 2-28". I selected one of the entries (1024 resolution in my case) and Clonezilla started up properly. Unfortunately no such option exists when running YUMI, so I would have to put each individual distro on its own USB stick, which of course I would never do.

ACCESSORIES I BOUGHT (AND CAN VERIFY THAT THEY WORK PROPERLY):

1) This is so I can hook directly to my wired LAN while at home.  I must say that WIFI is very speedy though and I have not had any glitches, so this was probably not necessary:
Cable Matters SuperSpeed USB 3.0 to RJ45 Gigabit Ethernet Network Adapter in Black

2) An SD card with decent random write / read speeds.  I installed all my Windows programs on this card (The D: drive in Windows), so it would not fill up the main drive (Which in fact it would have!).
SanDisk Extreme 32GB microSDHC UHS-1 Card with Adapter (SDSQXNE-032G-GN6MA)

3) A Gigabit capable Ethernet cable to go along with the Network Adapter above.  I ordered a red one so I could easily distinguish it from my other 100MB cables.
Mediabridge Cat5e Ethernet Patch Cable (15 Feet) - RJ45 Computer Networking Cord - Red

4) Logitech M325 Wireless Mouse.  I hate trackpads, no matter how good they are, and the consensus is that this one is bad.

5) The extended warranty.  I never order anything with extended warranties, because as they say it is a waste of money, but after reading (albeit only a couple) horror repair stories I went ahead with it.  It was really cheap anyway.

I received this product for review via the VINE program and was happy to have the chance to review this. As a Chromebook owner, I understand the product's built in space limitations in terms of hard drive. You are paying for a machine to use with online apps primarily. As such, this is a good option - the size is light and portable while still being full scale enough to use effectively for heavy writing. The touch of the keyboard is solid and the machine feels well made. You will either love or hate the blue color - I personally like it! My only concern with this product is the speed. I bought the HP Stream 13 to replace an aging Asus laptop that was starting to struggle...for one reason or another.  The Asus was a larger laptop that I had originally purchased to play Diablo 3 with my wife, however, we never really played.  As such, I've had this hulking monstrosity of a laptop for the last 3 years that was being used to browse the internet, check e-mail, and word process.  Basically, I could've used something much smaller, lighter, and more compact and still gotten the same performance.

I read a bunch of the reviews on the Stream and liked what I was reading.  I knew going in that I was going to be working with a machine that was probably not quite as fast as the laptop I was replacing...but the thing is, that laptop was running so poorly after the upgrade to Windows 10 that even if this Stream 13 IS slower, it probably wouldn't really be noticeable.

The machine arrived quickly, as is the case for all of my Amazon Prime shipments...well, most of them...lately it hasn't been the case, but that's not got anything to do with the Stream.

It was packaged well, in a nondescript box that was easy enough to open.  On the inside, the computer was supported with some nice foam and it was secured very well.

I popped it out and took a look.  I really like the color of it.  My last couple of laptops have been gray and black...it's nice to have a machine that's got a splash of color on it!!  I liked the feel of it, too...it's feel really kind of belies the price, in my opinion.  It looks and feels like a more expensive machine, that's for sure.

When opening it up, I also immediately took a liking to the keyboard.  I've got rather large hands, and on other small-ish laptops my hands often feel cramped, but this is not the case on the Stream 13.

I purchased the Windows 10 version of the Stream.  My experience with Windows 10 on both my Asus laptop and my Asus desktop has not been very positive...but I believe this to be more the result of Asus not releasing updated drivers in a timely manner, so the laptop in particular struggles because it's video card isn't running correctly.  I figured, though, that the Stream...with Windows 10 preinstalled...would probably at the very least have all of it's hardware work.

I fired up the Stream and went through all the basic setup stuff.  As soon as I could, I removed most of the bloatware from the computer.  I followed suggestions in other reviews here and on other sites and removed pretty much everything that I wasn't going to be using.  After getting those things removed, I immediately upgraded to the November 2015 update to Windows 10.  That was interesting, as it required about as much space as the laptop has available...but once it was installed, I was able to delete the Windows.old file and get my drive space back.

With the newest update to Windows on the machine, it runs very well.  I find it to be snappy for opening apps, browses the web relatively quickly, and is a joy to type on.  I find the Edge browser to every once in a while seem a bit slow, but I've also found that the Edge browser seems to load every image from a webpage before it will actually let you navigate the page, where other browers seem to load images as you scroll...the result, I believe, is that Edge is just as fast as the other browsers I'm using, it just seems a bit slower because it seems like it's catching for a second right after it gets to a page.

The MicroSD slot works great for adding storage space.  I'll be saving all of my photos, videos, and documents onto MicroSD cards and using them as almost like miniature hard drives...this will allow me to keep as much space on the Stream as I possibly can.

I've found that the complaints about this machine that others have are accurate.  The track pad isn't the greatest, and sometimes it doesn't register clicks or gestures.  This, however, for me isn't a concern because I'm wireless mouse user and I very rarely use a trackpad.  Even on my older and much more expensive Asus I found the trackpad difficult to use.  The screen also washes out at angles pretty quickly, but I also don't move around a whole lot while using my laptop.  It's...generally...on my lap directly in front of me, so there's no real reason for me to need to see it from an angle.

Overall, I'm very happy with this purchase.  It has a couple of downsides, but for the price I don't think you can really expect much more.  It's a solid machine that runs well, is easy to use, and gives you a full version of Windows.

I would recommend this computer to anyone looking for an inexpensive machine for basic computing such as web browsing, e-mail, organizing photos, or typing.

I purchased this laptop in July of 2015, looking for a laptop for coding, mainly with arduino and python, small projects like that, and school work.
For the price, it seemed like a no-brainer. It combined the low-cost, low-weight, disposability of a chromebook with the everyday functionality of a Windows laptop.

Pros:
+ Price point - Can't be beat, it's in a class of its own.
+ Weight - The lightest laptop I've ever owned. I could juggle these. (Note: Do not juggle HP Streams)
+ Durability - The Stream's 32 GB SSD means that it can take a bump or two without an issue. The plastic body also resists dents quite well. It does show chips and scrapes, however.
+ Ease of use - Obviously, with windows 10 installed the Stream is intuitive right out of the box. Another bonus is that it is incredibly easy to install Linux. Unlike Chromebooks, there is no real limit to the operating systems you can install.
+ Build quality - This goes hand in hand with durability. Very little flex in the keyboard, and very minor in the screen (What did you expect? it's 3mm of plastic)
+ Battery life - Man oh man, if my old Toshiba Satellite was a big rig, this thing's a Geo Metro. I'm unlucky if I get less than 2 days out of the Stream with the backlight turned down.

Cons:
- Speed - Obviously the Intel Celeron is no speed demon. But that's not the main issue. I tend to have many tabs open when doing research and other common internet activities, and 2 GB of RAM CANNOT handle that. This thing freezes up at about 3 open tabs in Firefox.
- Space - This laptop is advertised as a "cloud computing" machine, and i understand that. But with the HP bloatware installed, and Windows 10 (which is a large operating system, especially for this thing) You're left with about 5 GB for other programs. This is not enough for my needs, at least. I will say, however, that with a lightweight Linux distro installed, that is bumped up to about 20 GB. Better, but still not great. Again, depends what you use it for.

Summary - The HP Stream does what is is advertised to do quite well, and it doesn't claim to be anything it's not.
Should you buy one if you need to do intensive computing, or god forbid, gaming? No.
Should you buy it if you need to type google docs papers, or streaming (haha, that's it's name) Netflix, or leaving it in a classroom and not worry about anyone stealing it? Yes. Yes you should.

This is my initial review of the 11.6" HP Stream in the Violet color that has the newest processor (not last year's discontinued Horizon blue, nor the Orchid Pink Streams, which have less powerful processors and can be had for less than $199 now. Those can be picked up for $179 at Walmart, and other retailers.). All in all, I'm very pleased with the newer edition of the HP stream 11 with its faster processor.  It would be the bomb for anyone wanting a sleek and snappy budget laptop that doesn't play memory intense games, or do heavy graphic editing, etc. It's extremely portable, attractive and well built, super quiet, zippy and a terrific deal with the included 1 year of  Office 365 Personal. Plus you get an extra copy to use on your phone or tablet, too. It also comes with 1 year of 1 terabyte of cloud storage.  Mine did NOT come with the $25 Windows gift card, that promotion ended and doesn't ship with the newest ones. But it's still an incredible deal for all that this beauty does!
Admittedly, I am a power iPad user, in fact I have 3 going all day usually. But writing books on iPads even when they are equipped with Bluetooth keyboards is tedious.  So I when I saw the HP Stream came with a full year of Office 365 I bought it for the software mainly, and to have a copy of the software for my iPad, too.  The ideal consumer of this product is someone who wants a great deal on an ultra portable laptop that is zippy in performance and who wants to use it for basics, like using Office, browsing the web, online shopping, checking email, watching videos, streaming content , and for storage of photos and documents. It is NOT ideal in the least for heavy graphic editing, or for people who want to play 2D and 3D games that take incredible amounts of RAM, or for someone looking for a touch screen or tablet.
Like formortals, the top reviewer did,  I also removed some crapware (but keep in mind I have a newer model than he sent his nephew, so some of it was different.) That included:
The Wild Tangent game pack
Avast Secure Line
HP welcome and registration
Priceline
Apple Bonjour
cIsco LEAP and EAPFAST and PEAP
mcafee Antivrus (so I could default to the included Windows Defender)
I did not remove the HP support, nor the Card reader driver and I have over 11 gig left on the drive, actually almost 12 G and that's after installing the Pc Decrapifier, and CCleaner (both free downloads, just search) to remove the stuff I didn't want.  You can also uninstall preloaded apps through the Settings.  I did not change any internet explorer extensions, nor mess with the bios or registry. I will update this review if I make further changes. Anyone can remove crapware. Even me. It was easy, so don't let other reviewers put you off. CCleaner also offers a free defragmenter and that's what I used to defrag after I was done removing the bloat ware. The almost 12 G is also after adding the free CCleaner programs (all 4, including the defrag tool), and the free PCDecrapifier, and Chrome.  The HP Stream also comes with Cortana, HP's idea of a personal assistant...I will probably uninstall that as well.
Most of my gaming and streaming is done on my iPad Airs, so I won't comment on that as I did not purchase this for anything other than writing my books, performing research online, storing photos with the free year 1 terabyte cloud storage, and for creating my YouTube channels, though I will probably still rely on the iPads for most of the YouTube stuff. I did install Chrome and Magic Actions for YouTube. But another comment on the MS Edge browser...I like the fact you can write on the web!  But I'm not a fan of the Bing search engine.
If you do like movies it has the VUDU app pre installed where you can instantly watch any movie you buy with the VUDU label. Or you can remove it, too. It also has Microsoft's own music app. Streaming from Hulu or Netfflix works fine, no glitches, but I'm already spoiled from streaming on my IPads, so I doubt if I will use that much. The Netflix app is preloaded, along with  other popular links like Amazon, Priceline, etc. I removed the ones that I know I don't  use.  I'm using a 64G micro SDXC card for additional storage, and you can attach an external hard drive if you wish.  It meets my storage needs, and I write long books, with no problem storing the manuscripts.
This tablet performs better than my  $800 Dell laptop Inspiron 15..6 , though the screen is not as good in resolution.  However, I spend a lot of my day  on writing and research, and the screen does not bother me, even with my extremely poor vision.  Use the built in accessibility tools in Windows if you need to change your contrast, etc.
The sound from the speakers is surprisingly good for a laptop this inexpensive.
The violet color is closer to a nice blue.  (I actually thought they sent me the blue at first), and the HP emblem on top is a metallic purple, looks sweet! The newer models come in violet or a brighter cobalt blue. I do wish they had made a pink color similar to last years Orchid, but I really like the Violet, and it doesn't look like I'm a middle aged adult with a Hello Kitty obsession, especially if I take it to Panera or Starbucks to work on. This laptop is sleek and solid yet easy to carry anywhere because it's so light.  The white keys are a nice contrast on the gradient colored keyboard base. Easy to see and the keys have a nice feel and spring to them.
The battery life is terrific, the CPU processor is zippy,  and it boots very quickly.
The laptop stays remarkably cool, and it's soooo quiet! There is no fan since there is no hard drive, and it's weird if you are used to that fan purring when you're working away, but I've learned to treasure the silence!  I've read that with this type of drive storage, it's important to defrag often and regularly to keep it running swiftly with minimal errors.
I tried my off brand (Gearhead) Bluetooth mouse with it, but it didn't recognize it, and I'm not blaming the laptop, it's probably the mouse. Even after loading a new battery in the mouse, the Stream failed to pick up its presence. I will try a more popular brand of Bluetooth mouse.  Some people have commented on the trackpad, but I actually had no problem getting used to it, and you can adjust the settings if you don't care for the defaults. It's not too stiff or too mushy to click. It's pretty accurate when following my touch. EDIT: I installed a name brand mouse and it worked just fine.
The RAM memory cannot be upgraded on the recent models, either, but I have not found it to limit me in any way. It's plenty enough for the functions that this laptop does best.
My sincere thanks to the many articulate reviewers before me who were honest in their reviews and influenced my decision to go ahead and buy this little gem. I love it.  It has many wonderful features and I would buy this over a Chromebook any day. If you're considering a Chromebook, consider this instead, because it is much more capable and is incredibly priced for what you get.
IMPORTANT- read the reviews. Most of the people who are complaining don't understand what the concept behind this laptop is...they expect it to come with the features of a $750 laptop.  Or they don't understand how the storage works. One terabyte of cloud storage is a lot of storage!! And if you get the newer model like I did, the CPU is faster than the Horiizon blue or orchid colored models.  This is an incredible deal but it's not for anyone who expects it to do what a more expensive laptop would do.  If you don't know what
things are like the solid state drive is, look it up before you buy.
SUMMARY-- it's an incredible value but research what you are getting and don't be put off by the negative reviews. Most of those people didn't research the product or had unrealistic expectations or lack basic computer skills.  And many people bought these on Black Friiday not even researching the product just because of the price point.

First of all: this computer is NOT given enough brainpower to run the OS, let alone anything else! I can't even run pandora on it without major problems, and it won't run the version of MS Word IT COMES WITH. It hates firefox and even chrome runs slowly on it. And that touchpad! Ugh, gods save me from touchpads that are trying to be apple's single-click system. Gross! Don't get this! The only good thing about it is the monitor is super crisp and amazing and the machine doesn't overheat, but without any ability to add power or memory, you're better off using it as a super light satellite for only the most basic text editing or whatnot.

For reference, spouse and I both have one of these. This is what I ask my laptops to do:

1. Run pandora or 8tracks on a continuous basis (I need to listen to music all the time due to misphonia)
2. Run MS Word
3. Run firefox (I prefer firefox to chrome due to a wider range of accessibility apps)
4. Run telegram (a light IM app)

Sometimes, I would like this laptop to run audacity, which it does if that's ALL I'm doing.

This is not a lot to ask a computer to do simultaneously, right? This lappy can just about manage to run telegram. It's *atrociously* slow. My spouse has fared better, and has managed to get his to run:

1. Chrome
2. Telegram
3. iTunes
4. VLC media player

Not all at the same time, but in combinations of 1, 2, 3 or 1, 2, 4. He still fights with the damn thing on a daily basis, and comments that it is extremely slow, and very fussy.

In my mind? This computer *might* do better running a version of Linux, but as I'm not a supergeek programmer, that's not possible. HP 'stream'lined this machine TOO MUCH, and it's a waste of money, even though it's cheap. About the only thing going for it is that it's tinysmol and has a GREAT mic/speaker/sound system. If all I wanna do is record something on audacity, this is the machine I use.

What a waste of good hardware! It should have been made with more processing and memory capability, then it would have been able to take advantage of that sterling graphics and sound hardware!

At the current price ($209), this is a steal.
PROS & CONS
1. This isn't a computer for gaming or editing video, but for everything else it performs well. No problems streaming video, e.g.
2. It has a very small hard drive. You're meant to use cloud storage, although if your needs are modest, you could pop a 64 GB flash drive into the port (there are 3 USB ports) and triple the amount of storage (to 96 GB).
3. Excellent sound.
4. Professional reviews indicate that the battery life is below average (about 6 hours), but this hasn't been an issue for me.
5. It's cute.

No, it doesn't perform like my MacBook Pro, but it's a fraction of the price. It's ultra-portable, and for the price, it's a surprisingly useful Windows-based laptop.

I bought this computer just for something portable I can take and use on the go to get some light work done. It does comes with 32gb of on-board storage but you will run out really quickly. Just like any laptop you buy from a manufacturer it will come with a lot of bloatware, program you really do not need that will take up storage and each up that 2gb of ram. I suggest that yo claim your free one year subscription to Office 365 and 1TB of Onedrive cloud storage. Once you have claimed that I suggest you do a full clean install of Windows. That means opening up settings, go to recovery, and reset the pc. It will ask you if you want to keep your files or remove everything. Choose remove everything. This will do a fresh clean install of windows without all of the bloatware. Once your computer starts back up you will easily have about around 10gb of free space (it depends). This space you get back you can use for programs and windows update.

For storing Documents, photos, videos, etc. I highly recommend you get a micro SD card for storage and set the computer to automatically use the micro SD card for storing documents, programs (some will let you choose where to install them), and other things etc. This means going to settings again, select system then choose storage. Under Save Locations move everything to your microSD card.

As for performance its pretty good for the price you pay. I suggest not having anything running in the background of your computer at idle except for system task. You only have 2gb or ram and more or less 1gb or that ram will be used by the operating system. That means you have about 1gb for programs that you will run on the desktop. If I am not doing anything too specific for web browsing I would more likely use the Microsoft Edge browser since it takes up less system resources than Chrome.

Other than that you get a pretty good computer for light web browsing and word processing. Its a great inexpensive first computer for first year college students or students in general or people who don't do many things other than light video watching (you can watch one 1080p video from Youtube but when you open another video and have two running at the same time the system throttles heavily mostly due to memory and processor bottle necking), word processing, and light web browsing.

I hope you have your reading glasses on, because it's about to be a long one. Grab a loved one and a hot beverage, sit back, and let me spin you a yarn that'll put you in the computer buying mood.

First and foremost, this computer comes with Windows 10 Home Edition. I have a bit of a problem with Microsoft and Windows 10 since I wear a tinfoil hat on most days and believe that without your knowing consent, the operating system is keeping track of data from you and using it to tailor make advertisements for you, not only while browsing websites, but on your own start menu. If Microsoft and Advertisers get that sort of information about you, who else is getting that information? Do you care? Do you have "nothing to hide"? Am I going down a dark path you don't want to think about right now?

All of what I said just now is factual, just sort of look it up in your free time. Fortunately, you can turn off pretty much all of these things aside from Telemetry data (non-identifiable information about how your computer is being used such as program history and crash reports) that goes straight to the codemonkeys at Microsoft to help them make a better update in the future. Unlike Windows 7 and Windows 8, unfortunately, you will be getting that update, as Windows 10 Home comes with no way to turn off automatic updates. Technically, neither does Windows 10 Professional or Enterprise, but they do come with access to Group Policy Editor, which will allow advanced users to change the way Windows 10 handles automatic updates beyond what's advertised on the user friendly menus. In general, you're going to want to install some other OS on this little machine, because Windows 10 Home is criminally lacking. Perhaps you may want to downgrade to 8, or upgrade to a better version of 10, but unfortunately for me, it doesn't seem that 7 is an option as HP has seemingly discontinued support for drivers necessary to 7's installation. More experimentation for me, I suppose.

Now, I know I just slammed Windows 10 pretty hard, but in truth, there's still a Microsoft operating system somewhere in there trying to help you have an enjoyable experience. Beyond all of the strange and potentially privacy invading settings, it's a solid operating system with a lot of useful (and worthless) applications built in. Out of concern for my own privacy I connected this laptop to my Wifi only long enough to download essential software for on the go work, and I haven't allowed it access to any network since. The connection was solid, though. Now, let's get to the part that's going to aggravate most normal users:

This is an HP PC first and foremost, and that means it's going to be preinstalled with about 50 pounds of worthless, redundant bloatware. I was actually surprised how little there was on this machine compared to devices I've purchased in the past, but it's still there and you're still going to want to remove it, along with the one year subscription to McAfee because it's just trash. The HP software tends to make the processor go up to 100% use quite often, so with it still on there, you're going to notice slowdowns for no apparent reason. Just poor optimization on the software's part, I assume. Fortunately, it's easy enough to take this stuff off, and it'll also let you reclaim a good chunk of your relatively small Hard Drive, which is solid state. The read times are incredible, and really, 32gb is enough for you to store the OS and any larger programs that you want to run quickly. For those of you who want to store your pictures and video and music and such - that adds up fast. I suggest buying an external hard drive, as it'll go at lightning speeds when it interfaces with the USB 3.0 port included on this laptop.

Physically speaking, this laptop is exactly what I wanted - a mobile computing option that is durable, more usable than a tablet, but still small enough to fit in a bag while I'm out and about. This laptop measures in at about 1 foot and some change in length, and its width is no more significant than one of those black and white composition books. It's incredibly lightweight, and while closed, the battery seems practically endless. With proper power management (dim screen, few programs, etc) you can get a workday's worth of use out of this little thing off of one charge. As strange as it is to say, my personal favorite part about this laptop is that it has no fans, and really, no moving parts at all. Not only does this eliminate weight, it really allows you to use and store this laptop anywhere without worrying what kind of dust it's going to suck up. Most people love having their laptops on their lap, or on a bed, and unfortunately, dust and fuzz gets sucked up in there and eventually becomes a problem, causing the processor to overheat or the fan to outright stop running in extreme cases. It makes no noise and keeps itself cool based purely on how little power it consumes. Even though it has a completely plastic shell, that tells me it was designed to last.

The keyboard being white on an otherwise all indigo laptop (and yes this is a very deep bluish purple, not violet as the name suggests) is a little disorienting, and I don't look forward to the fact that eventually, no matter how clean my hands are, the keyboard's going to start to look dirty. I would have much preferred black keys, or y'know, keys that match the color. The touchpad is honestly one of the worst I've ever used. The tracking can be jumpy and the buttons barely function. If you don't have a wireless mouse to go with this, Logitech makes many great ones at reasonable prices, look into them. I don't consider that worthy of detracting a star from this otherwise stellar laptop just because so much about the design makes me really happy.

You're hard pressed to find better for the price - I couldn't find a better deal even with Black Friday/Cyber Monday factored in. Some of that may depend on the kind of specifics I was looking for, but in general I'm happier with this purchase than I ever was with my old laptop which ran me twice as much as this one. My biggest gripes are honestly nitpicks about the fact that there isn't a model that comes with an AMD processor (I dislike Intel) and HP's apparent lack of concern for supporting Windows 7, even though Windows XP still received support for much longer after it became "legacy". On the advanced end of the spectrum, the BIOS is a bit lacking and doesn't seem to allow you access to the really advanced options unless you pull of some intense registry editing. I'm not too fond of the "return" of the Start Menu, since it's less of a start menu and more of 8's awful home menu squeezed into one little area. A step in the right direction, yes, but I don't want that pointless clutter in my start menu. A program called Classic Shell helps you get around that, and it's absolutely free.

Overall a great purchase for all levels of experience.

I've had my Blue Stream13 for a year now, and think it's great. I'm a power user, with high-spec Lenovo and Dell ultra-light laptops at home and office. I was in a situation last year where I needed a laptop quickly, so I walked into a store and bought this. I haven't regretted it. I use it mostly as a netbook (that is, I open files from my online SugarSync drive), web-browsing, and for Exchange-based e-mail -- I like that I can use whatever Windows programs I want, unlike being tied to Google apps if I use a Chromebook. I did buy a 64GB microSD and keep a copy of my data files there; they're not always up to date, as SugarSync won't look at an external drive, but this way I do have access to old files easily if I need them. Because it's relatively cheap (I know $225 isn't nothing, but I'm in a situation where that's money I can afford to lose), I didn't worry when I took it traveling internationally to a variety of high-potential-theft places -- even if it was damaged, lost, or stolen, I hadn't lost my main machine or a huge investment. For about 6 weeks last summer, it was my only machine, and I didn't regret it. I don't use high-processing-speed programs (I don't watch a lot of video, I don't edit video, I'm not running AutoCAD, etc.) -- just plain office software most of the time. I'm quite happy.

EXCEPT:  the touchpad is awful.  It simply does not respond properly to clicks and gestures, at least half the time.  We'll use a mouse instead.

Windows 10 is an acquired taste, which we are in the process of acquiring.  At least it's better than Windows 8.  The jury is still out on the Microsoft Edge browser.

First, let me acknowledge that I am in no way a computer expert.  My review of this product is merely my humble opinion by making a simple comparison between the current product and equipment that I've previously used.

The trackpad for this Notebook does not interact properly and I often have delayed responses - particularly when attempting a right click.  I found that I could avoid this by using a USB mouse.  The slowness however drove me crazy and made we want to throw the Notebook out the window.

You will need to delete a lot of garbage that is pre-loaded on this computer (temporary files, etc.) to free up the 32 Gig hard drive.  Once mine was cleaned up, I had 12 gigs left.  With a 32 Gig hard drive, 64 bit operating system, and only 2 gigabits of memory - this system is SLOW.  I updated a tablet at the same time as this laptop (the exact same updates were needed) and this laptop was much slower in uploading the updates.

I really dislike that there is so little storage space on this laptop.  Users will have to be constantly saving photos, data/documents, files, music, etc. on the cloud storage as the 32 gig storage space will not allow much long term storage (most smart phones have more storage space than this).  This means that you will be uploading everything on the cloud, and when you need to use it again - you need to then download it. If you live in rural areas and your internet provider is slow, you may have wait times that are not insurmountable but very annoying when uploading and downloading.  The fee after the 1-year of free storage appears to be currently priced at $7 monthly.

I find that this Notebook is practical for browsing the internet but for my use - that's about it.  I really don't like it and wish I would have realized that you cannot expand the RAM or storage space. The small 32 gig storage space ensures that you MUST use the cloud as opposed to having it be for optional long term storage.

This looked like an good laptop for basic use, so I ordered it. I find it to be fast enough for basic tasks, with a solid keyboard and decent screen.

There are some good points to this laptop:

+ I wanted this device for basic word processing on the go, and for that purpose it is very good. It is not as convenient to pack as my former 11 inch, and at 4 lbs is a bit heavy, but is fine for a backpack.

+ Overall I'm finding that I like the size - the screen is easy to see and quite readable. Some folks will complain about the relatively low screen resolution (1366x768), but in fact this resolution makes it excellent for basic word processing; it is much easier to read (and use, overall) than my more expensive Dell convertible.

+ I like that HP bundled Office 365 with it, with a one year subscription. The files are executed off the hard drive, which makes it run faster.

+ The keyboard is a bit small, but has very good backing and is absolutely silent in operation - great for a classroom. I like it for touch typing.

+ The overall construction seems quite sturdy.

+ The dedicated keys for home, page up, page down, end, print screen, and etc. are separate and easy to use. This is a fully functional keyboard, unlike some models where the keys have dual use.

+ The touchpad works very well, with a solid left and right click. More importantly, the keyboard is situated such that I was not constantly accidentally hitting the touchpad and moving the cursor. I've had some laptops for which I've actually had to disable the touchpad because it interfered with typing - not this one.

+ With the default power saving settings, I was able to get 5 hours of screen time. I think this could be pushed with tweaking and turning on airplane mode.

+ OK, it is only cosmetic, but I really like the blue color. In fact, the overall design is stylish, while not sacrificing sturdy build quality.

+ Three USB ports, although only one is 3.0. What I don't like is that the 3 port is not colored blue, which is industry standard.

+ The 3mm port supports both headset and microphone, which means you can plug in an earbud or basic handsfree for use with Skype and etc. This leaves the USB ports free for other tasks.

+ The full size HDMI port is great for playing movies.

+ The supplied charger is very small (a mini brick), which will fit better in the backpack.

There are some things that are less good.

- I found that the hard drive has only 15 GB free when booted up. Fortunately, it does have a MicroSD storage slot (unusual, since most have a standard SD), which can be used to store files. They also provide a one year subscription to OneDrive for a full TB of data.

- The screen is not touch sensitive, but at this price point that is just a note, not a drawback.

- The antivirus is only good for a single month, and ironically, it looks like I will have to uninstall it and reinstall the same program so that I can register it. Mcafee allows unlimited computers to use the same license at home, and it actually works very well.

- There is some HP bloatware, but that can be easily removed. This is frustrating on a machine with limited storage space.

- I did notice that the laptop has a definite way of operating - occasionally it will slow down for a brief second. But it is not noticeable in general, and did not detract from using it. I attribute this to the Celeron processor and limited memory. You have to work with the machine, rather than fighting it.

- When using this laptop, you will want to stay with the basics. This machine is not at all suited for gaming, or heavy database / spreadsheet use. Programs can take a few seconds to come up, but then they run fine. I don't plan on running more than a couple of major programs at a time. I'm actually impressed with how well it works with only 2GB of main memory. Once everything completes the boot process, it runs well. I did not bother running PC diagnostics - if you are interested in those numbers, don't bother with this machine!

Summary: A very decent laptop for student use, at a great price. Highly recommended for light word processing and excel.

I recently purchased this laptop 3 months ago for $200. I purchased it for the purpose of using it for college and I needed one to do work and study. I will be going over some pros and cons with this laptop and will also give it a evaluation.
Pros:
-This laptop is cheap and affordable. For $200 there aren't going to be much that are better than this
-It also came with a $25 Microsoft gift card and 1 free year of Microsoft Office. Now those two items alone can be worth up to $100, probably more. Spending $200 on a cheap laptop and getting at least $100 back? Ill take that deal again any day.
-Its reliable; while this is a cheap and reliable laptop, it has also gotten pretty slow over the months. At first it was pretty fast and I was amazed. Then as time went on it started to show why it was only $200. Although its gotten pretty slow, it still gets the job done and hopefully (fingers crossed) it doesnt get slower as its still usable and reliable now.
-The life on the battery is pretty good. Ive used my laptop for 7 hours straight before doing work and listening to music, and I still had battery left over when I finished.
- This laptop also shipped to me in Windows 10, which is amazing. Unfortunately it does take up most of your space as this laptop doesnt have that move space.
Cons:
-The keyboard takes some getting used too, and after 3 months Im still getting used to it. Its pretty small and if you have big hands, you should probably buy a separate keyboard that suits you.
-Clicking things can also be frustrating. Whenever trying to click on things, sometimes the computer doesnt register it and I have to click it 2 or 3 times. Its as if the key needs to be clicked on harder than most keys.
-No storage space. Even though it says its 32GB its not. Also after Windows 10 theres little to no room for storage. So if you're thinking of downloading a big program or anything I would advise against it; this is also probably why its been running slow lately as it keeps saying Im about to run out of storage room.
For $200 this is a pretty decent laptop. Would I spend an extra $200 dollars for a better more efficient laptop? Probably yeah. Does this get the job done? Yes, Ive written multiple essays, and still do, and Ive also studied a lot with it. If you just need a cheap laptop to get work done then buy this laptop. If you're looking for anything else Id advise you to buy another laptop.

Okay, so I`ve had this computer about a week so take that into account on my review.  I have read every single review and was prompted to give my review because I take issue with many of the things I have read.  First, I have the blue one, not the purple one that so many seem to want to avoid the "crapware".  Microsoft is selling the purple one in their store and, at first, I was tempted to take mine back to Walmart and buy that one because of so much fuss about the crapware.  However, as I played with mine I realized I was not having any issues with it.  I did eliminate the programs I did not need like bonjour and a few others to free up some space.  I upgraded to Windows 10, put in all the updates and added flash player, java and firefox.  I currently have 8.3 GB of free space and added a 32 GB SD card.

I want everyone to know you do not have to be tech-savvy to have a good running machine so do not be put off by what you may have read in regards to eliminating everything.  I have all my HP software still on my PC and it works great.  Furthermore, I find the HP utility center to be very helpful.  Maybe it does effect the speed but I certainly have not found that to be a problem.  The only issue I have is with the touch pad which many times requires another touch or two to select an item.  I can live with that.  I tried Youtube and had no problems viewing the various clips as well as playing a movie from my USB drive.  Bottom line, I absolutely love this little computer.  It does exactly what I want, is easy to carry and the battery lasts a very long time.  Buy it, you won`t be disappointed unless, of course, you get a lemon in which case you simply return it and get another one.

Final thoughts:  I`m thinking of uninstalling firefox, not because there is a problem but because Microsoft Edge works very well.  I see no need for two browsers.  Also, we are coming up on Black Friday so you might want to wait and see if these little gems are discounted further.  I got mine at Walmart for $179 ($193.50 with tax).  Microsoft still wants $199 as of this writing.  Hope this review has helped someone.  Enjoy the Stream and happy computing!

Review of HP Stream,
I purchased the HP Stream 13 so my son who is a middle schooler could have an inexpensive and light weight laptop to take back and forth to school with him everyday.

My son and I both like the laptop; it has a very sleek, and attractive design. I purchased a 64 GB MicroSD to give him more storage, and I deleted whatever applications I felt were unnecessary to increase speed and startup time. A November 12, 2014 comment on Amazon.com helped me sift through and delete applications that could be considered bloatware.

The laptop is mainly used by my son for watching assigned homework videos, for typing reports, and doing light research. My son has not had to take it to school yet, but its light weight makes it very easy to transport.

The keyboard is easy to type on, however the mouse pad can be unresponsive at times. Weve solved that by getting him an external mouse. Overall I think this computer fills a gap for first laptop users (young kids) and for other users looking for a Windows computer at a Chromebook price. Plus the one year subscription to Office Online, and a $25 Microsoft App Store gift card made this purchase worth it.

Purchased two of these for my daughters (5 and 8) and they are great. Very durable and easy to use. My girls love them and I'm happy that they no longer monopolize MY laptop for their games and school stuff!

She loves it and I can use parent settings to protect her. It seems to be pretty durable too. Great buy! Thank you Amazon.
The laptop is fine. Windows 10 not so. It hides all the apps you need and pushes all the ones you have to pay. After a couple weeks I have it almost where I want it.
Wish I could get a refund, has been a slow piece of junk since week 1. Extremely disappointed.

I needed a laptop for school but didn't want to spend a ton. I had been looking at Chromebooks but didn't want to give up the Windows operating system. This was PERFECT for my needs, it's basically a step up from a Chromebook.

My son was wanting a new laptop and after checking out a few online he decided he wanted us to buy him this HP Stream. We ordered the Magenta colored one for him and the color is really pretty. It comes with Windows 8.1, has 32GB of storage and 2 GB memory, which was just fine for him since he is just using it for stuff like Facebook. If he decides  he needs more space there is a spot for an SD card.  The screen is 11.6 in. and the laptop weighs a little over 2 lbs.  so he can take it wherever he goes. One thing we did not realize until he received it is that it does not have a CD drive.  The keyboard and mouse are easy to use and he hasn't had a problem with them sticking at all. Sometimes it does take some time to get things to load correctly but then again that is to be expected with a cheaper laptop.  He uses it a lot so he really likes that he can be on it for 7 or 8 hours before he needs to charge it. He has had it for a few months and is really glad that he decided to have us buy this one for him.
For a 200 dollar laptop I was surprised. It runs great it is completely quit due to the fan less design and does everything I need it too.
Works as well as expected for the price. Is a little slower than preferred but it was only 200 dollars. I have had it for over a month and haven;t had a single issue with it.

Please note:  this laptop cannot easily update to Windows 10 due to the lack of storage space after the initial setup process / downloading of Windows 8.1 updates.  After all Windows 8.1 updates have been downloaded, you will only have roughly 4 GB storage space remaining for documents, pictures, and music on the internal storage.

Pro:
+ Build quality is excellent and lightweight (excellent for a student)
+ Unique & Colorful design
+ Flash based storage helps make this sub $300 Windows laptop comparable in speed to most Chromebooks
+ Regular sized HDMI port included
+ Excellent speakers
+ Processor and memory specs are sufficient for most users interested in light gaming, web browsing, and email.

Cons:
- The recovery partition takes up half of the 32GB storage space (Difficult process is required if interested in updating to Windows 10)
- Bloated with junk software which requires manual removal

**Disclaimer - If this laptop updated to the free Windows 10 as advertised, I would have given it 5 stars.  In my opinion, I think most users who use this product for a few months with Windows 8.1 and then later decide to update to Windows 10...would be frustrated with having to backup all their files and then resort to a manual / grueling process for updating to Windows 10 by manually deleting the recovery partition.

The HP Stream 11.6 represents a cost-engineered laptop that makes decisions on what to leave in, and leave out to meet a low target price. With this in mind, I didn't expect a powerhouse, but instead a small, lightweight laptop for conventional computer tasks (Web surfing, Skype, Office). Given this low threshold, the laptop succeeds.

So, what is left out? The storage is slim; of a reported 28 GB of space, only 12.5 GB of space is free. Clearly, the thought is that this laptop will leverage cloud storage for much of it's storage space, whether it be Microsoft's or someone else (Dropbox is pre-installed, with a 25 GB capacity). The screen is decent, if not stellar with good viewing angles. The body is all plastic, in my case made of a nice shade of blue. The webcam offers an image of a entry level webcam - a slightly noisy image. The trackpad is not the best I have used, but with a little tweaking it is acceptable - tracking is a little sluggish even at a faster speed.

So - the positives -  it is reasonably snappy. It boots quickly, applications launch with little hesitation. It is true that there are faster SSD drives out there, but the included drive works well for it's intended purpose. The keyboard is actually decent; a little plasticy but action is acceptable and layout is comfortable. I tried Office, Paint. Net, Chrome, playing back Youtube videos, and it all worked fine. It ships with Windows 10, which is a significant improvement over Windows 8. The start menu is actually quite useful, and for myself - the mail client works well - and will work easily with email sources other than Microsoft's (such a Google). The laptop is fairly lightweight and the case is rigid (despite it being plastic). Battery life is surprisingly good; I was able to get 9 hours of use, a combination of email, web surfing, watching videos, working in Microsoft word and Paint.net. It does include some extraneous applications that most will ignore, or delete, plus a trial version of McAfee. It comes with Office 365 for a year. It has a microSD slot, an easy and cheap way to add additional storage for files to the laptop.

The laptop is clearly targeted for those who might otherwise buy a cheap Chromebook. For some the HP Stream may be a better option, simply because the Windows OS allows for more flexibility in applications being installed, keeping mind that there is a hard limit due to the scant storage space for applications. It may make sense for someone who a few years ago would have been tempted by a netbook (the HP Stream is better than many due to it's keyboard). It might make sense as a laptop for a kid, or for someone who just wants an inexpensive laptop to take to a coffee shop and get some work done (and in fact, that's what I've used it for). It is true that for a bit more someone can get a more capable laptop (prices have plummeted) so that should definitely be taken into consideration. But as it stands on it's own, it is a decent, inexpensive laptop that is a viable alternative to a Chromebook

"Oh well," I thought. I'll just upgrade the memory and install it myself. Nope.  Can't be upgraded.  It gets worse.  The video driver needs an upgrade. Not enough memory. About 10% of the time you switch between apps, the screen just blacks out, especially between PowerPoint and Microsoft edge. Sometimes just switching tabs on internet explorer causes the screen to go black. When it comes back on, I get a message that tells me to install critical updates for the video driver. Well I can't. Worse yet, about half the time that the screen goes black, it doesn't come back on so it has to be manually restarted. This stupid computer easily triples the amount of time that it takes me to do homework. Time to bite the bullet and buy a Mac or something else that actually performs.

We own three computers. I run Window 8.1 for web site development and maintenance. This was purchased to replace my laptop for use when traveling. The unit bought is the 13.3 inch, non-touch screen, Windows 10 HP laptop. It had too many problems out of the box; I returned it. First, the sound was the worst I have ever heard on any computer, (very, very tinny), which I figured I could somehow fix later, so I continued the installation. It failed three times copying files from a remote server over the internet to the local hard drive; the failures hung the program, which had to be killed from the Task Manager. Three other times, when copying from a USB flash drive to the local hard drive it also failed, once giving the message "not enough memory," yet there was 12 GB free; that USB port, (the one on the left), was then dead until the computer was restarted, but the flash drive worked in either of the other two right ports just fine. Is it a problem with Windows 10 or the Stream or both? I don't know, but I am unwilling to spend more than the 7 hours it took to remove the bloatware, install the programs I use every day, and then remove it all before returning it.

The good news is Amazon's return policy; that is why there is a two-star review instead of one-star review.

So this thing is basically a tablet with a keyboard and lots of ports to connect peripherals. The ports were my reason for buying this instead of a tablet - you can get data, applications, etc off of it without a network or cloud.

I followed suggested, "remove crapware", instructions in other's reviews and as they say it runs smoothly thereafter. I can open a bunch of tabs in Chrome and the CPU averages about 6% and I'm not having any trouble with typical browsing. Hulu and Netflix work smoothly and the HDMI out runs without skipping at 1080p.

Battery life is at least as advertised. I use it most of the day without plugging in, regardless of what I'm doing with it.

It's very light weight so is easy to sit on the couch with or carry around. It feels kind of cheap / plasticky - like when the lid is closed and you carry it around the two halves aren't secured, they, "clack", a little. I type for a living and I can type pretty well on the chicklet keys. For $225 I guess I can't complain about the build - it all works.

Turning DTS off is a big deal if you use the microphone for Skype, etc. With it on you sound like you're in a tunnel. There aren't any visible DTS applications anywhere, you have to type, "dts", at the search prompt and run the located program and turn it off. It's not a studio quality mic but at least you sound like you.

The 32 gB storage is really bare minimum, you don't really have much room to install anything. It comes with 12 mos of Office, but you have to install it and yes, it takes space. I installed Office and just a few other applications and I have 6 gB left. Even though I expected this I am still surprised how little space is left and I'm getting used to doing everything off USB sticks. Right now I'm too chicken to update to WIndows 10, mostly because the disk space thing leaves me thinking I'd wind up with a rescue operation and a lot of wasted time and the words about, "drivers won't be recognized", spooked me a little.

The update would be almost complete when it would notify me, without reason, that it would not work. I was eventually successful using an external hard drive.

This is a handy extra laptop. While it isn't great, the HP Stream 11.6-Inch Laptop (Intel Celeron, 2 GB RAM, 32 GB SSD, Cobalt Blue), will be a sturdy addition to your home.

Essentially, it feels like a toy. I mean that in the best way. It is colorful and feels less dainty than my other laptop (a medium-end Windows-based product). As it is much smaller, and because the price-point is low, it is easy to grab-and-go into meetings.

It is all in there, everything you expect in a Windows machine. That's a plus. The downside is the hardware. The thing is slow, the resolution is weak and the keyboard feels awkward. Granted, because the it is smaller, the keyboard is also smaller, but it is difficult to get used to.

I like it as an extra computer on which I don't store anything like photos or documents. It is excellent as a way to Skype, YouTube and Netflix, as well as some insignificant surfing. Bring it to the beach without worry.

Don't think of this as a laptop, but as more of a tablet (minus the ability to use a touch screen).

I installed Linux Mint on mine. If you're hoping to get one of these to install Linux, know that Windows has moved away from traditional BIOS. It's not impossible to remove Windows and install a less restrictive OS, but you'll have to work around UEFI, turn off secure boot, turn on legacy boot and manually navigate your USB's files to find the UEFI boot files. It sounds difficult but if you can deal with traditional BIOS, you can deal with UEFI.

This is a tiny, small inexpensive made portable demi-netbook, suitable for a child or someone whose computer needs are focused on internet activity or someone who doesn't have the money to purchase something more durable with a larger screen.  It came pre-loaded with windows 10, and full of software 'free for a while' that you will have to pay for after the subscription period ended. It is not super fast, but not super slow, although my 5 year old dell runs faster. For me it is functional, but closer to a toy than a piece of serious hardware. But if you take into mind the audience you are purchasing it for, it might suit a certain type of user. Someone who wants to chat, check facebook, browse Amazon, and whose vision is great, might do well on this small tablet-sized machine. For a person trying to do more, this machine might be too limited.

It boots, and immediately wants to find your wifi router. Connecting to wifi was simple and easy. I was on the internet in minutes, mostly because I had to add this machine's mac address to my mac address filter.

Looks wise, it is cute. It is bright blue plastic, resembling a toy computer. The keyboard is responsive, the track pad is a single piece, the screen narrow and tiny but appealing with a backdrop of pre-selected icy snow.

I probably wouldn't purchase a machine like this, as I need more robust power, but if you are looking to gift grandma with a computer to check her email this might be something you might buy- as long as granny has good vision. I would be concerned about using this for children, as it is a heavily internet reliant piece of hardware, but that's each parents decision to make.

This machine doesn't blow me away, but it isn't bad either. It is a solid piece of technology for what it is.

This product was delivered on July 17th and worked fine for about 4-5 weeks even after I suffered some of the same problems starting it up that others have described.  It was purchased for my wife who only used it to check emails occasionally or read the paper online.  Then her health declined sharply near the middle of August and the laptop (still working well) was placed aside on the charger.  For the next 6-8 weeks it was only booted up a few times a week to update the anti-virus protection, etc.  The last week I went to boot it up and it is DEAD.  Won't start on battery; won't start with power cord plugged in; just blank.  Power cord has been checked; power on switch has been checked; NOTHING.

There is no indication that it is getting power except that the bottom is very warm so power is going somewhere.  I don't know if this HP version has a safety cutoff switch or not.  I can't return it to Amazon because it didn't break down in the first 30 days; and, I don't know how HP will try to address this as a warranty matter.  I certainly don't want to waste a lot of time trying to contact them, but I guess I'll have to ... VERY FRUSTRATING.

It failed during an attempted upgrade to Windows 10, but the operating system files for the upgrade have been partially installed by Microsoft.  As a result, I have no disc space left:  it is all allocated to Windows files.  It is not "Windows 10 Ready" as advertised.
It has never been able to run my peripherals:  a projector or an external DVD player.  On 2/11/16, the power cord intake broke.  The pin inside the intake is loose and it appears to be chipped.  I do not handle my electronic devices roughly.  I unplugged it to pack it and take it away from home, and when I tried to plug it back in the cord would no longer fit.  Now, of course, the battery is dead.  Its best feature is its light weight, but this prevents me from using it as a doorstop.  I can't think of any other practical use for it.

When I emailed the seller to cancel the order, it suddenly shipped:  seriously, later the same day, it shipped.  I don't recommend the seller, and I have no love for HP. The 11.6 inch Stream by HP is a lightweight, well-made system that would be great as a first system for the younger student, or anyone that needs a light duty system to get them through simple tasks. The keyboard is pretty much full-sized, and very comfortable. I compare this to theAsus Transformer Book 10.1-inch 32GB Detachable 2-in-1 Touch Laptop/Tablet T100TA With Keyboard Dock - Grey (Certified Refurbished)(64 GB Storage) that I recently bought myself, and love. Comparing the two systems, I love the wider spread keys of the HP's keyboard, and the lighter weight of the system overall, when holding it in the hand, but I like that my ASUS has a touchscreen tablet/screen that I can disconnect and use independent of the keyboard dock. The resources of the two systems are about the same, so the performance is similar, as well. Because of that, I find the HP to be a bit slow to respond when multiple tabs are open, especially considering all the bloatware that comes loaded on the system. Once the greater portion of that is removed, you're likely to find that you have more than just the 15 GB of system memory that my system currently has, pre-bloatware removal. It's easy enough to pick up a Micro SD card to add more storage to this system, but it's never going to run high-demand games or any other resource-demanding software... of course, it's not meant to run that sort of software, either. Overall, I like this system. The colors it's offered in are great and bright, thus very eye-catching. The resources are on-point for a basic, travel-friendly netbook. For the price, you really can't go wrong with the HP Stream, as long as you keep in mind what it's meant to do.

After consulting various technicians I felt robbed to hear that there isn't much that can be done. I will be resuming by part time courses in September so this is quite frustrating.
I attempted to seek product support here but there is none available for this product. I am so disappointed.
The one star is for the quick delivery service.

I do not like this computer at all, but I needed a new one on a budget a few years ago, so I bought this one. However, it seems HP is not doing extremely well at the moment, and I now realize that purchasing this was a mistake. The disk space is always low due to the constant updates, and someone needs to go to the updates and find old updates to uninstall. However, this is easier said than done. With countless files under an old update, uninstalling the wrong one can leave  a computer crippled and even completely broken. I am upgrading to a more expensive laptop with 4 times the memory after dealing with this piece of junk.

That being said, I never was able to even install Microsoft Office, Excel, and the like. Any program I installed for school was immediately uninstalled once I was finished with it. This still did nothing to help with my memory issues. For someone who deletes my downloads, temporary files, and does not store pictures or any large files, the memory still was not enough! Google Docs and Drive was my savior when it came to utilizing this computer for homework, etc. Without its existence this computer is useless. I would not recommend this computer to any student, spent $500 more and get something else.
Cute color, simple basic laptop.
